story:
(English text below)

Umgebindehaus

Wir sind eine 3-köpfige Familie: Mutter Susanne, Vater Carl-Philip und Sohn Luke. Wir wohnen in einem Plattenbau im 5. Stock, was sehr anstrengend für meine (gelegentlich schwangere) Frau ist. Wir wollen nur noch zurück in die Natur.

Die Oberlausitz ist eine ostsächsische Bergregion an der Grenze zu Polen und Tschechien. Sie ist bekannt für ihre typischen Umgebindehäuser - 200-500 Jahre alten Häusern, die komplett aus Holz, Lehm und Natursteinen gebaut sind. Eine Blockstube im Erdgeschoss gewährleistet gute Dämmung selbst im tiefsten Winter. Ein Fachwerk um die Blockstube herum gebaut setzt weitere Stockwerke auf.

Viele Umgebindehäuser sind in gutem Zustand, weil sie bewohnt sind. Aber es gibt auch verlassene Umgebindehäuser. Wir wollen in solch eines ziehen und dies sanieren. Wir wollen so viel wie möglich originale Materialien einsetzen, da diese Jahrhunderte halten werden.

 

Was wir tun wollen

 

Alte Holzhäuser sind gemütlich, doch dieses Haus wurde das letzte mal vor dem zweiten Weltkrieg renoviert. Es gibt eine Menge zu tun, bevor es sich dort wieder komfortabel wohnen lässt:

     
  • Neue Fenster einsetzen
  • Lehmputz an der Fassade erneuern
  • Dämmung des Unterbodens mit Glasschotter (momentan ist nur Erdreich darunter)
  • Dabei Einbau einer Fußbodenheizung
  • Erneuerung der Elektrik
  • Wasserleitungen und Plumpsklo durch modernere Varianten ersetzen

Wir können dieses Haus für 20.000 Euro kaufen. Unser Plan ist, noch weitere 60.000 Euro in die Renovierung zu investieren. Insgesamt benötigen wir also etwa 80.000 Euro. Wir haben das Kampagnen-Ziel auf 25.000, sodass wir zumindest das Haus und einige Werkzeuge kaufen können, um anzufangen.

Sollten wir mehr Geld einsammeln, als wir brauchen, ist das kein Problem. Das Haus hat 3 Stockwerke, von dem wir vorerst nur das erste renovieren. Die anderen Stockwerke reservieren wir für Gäste und mehr Kinder.

Warum solltest du uns unterstützen?

Meine Frau ist Vollzeit-Mutter und ich bin Selbstständiger - beste Voraussetzungen für eine Kreditvergabe, oder? Zusätzlich halten wir nicht viel von Zins-Verschuldungen (ganz abzusehen von der Grundschuld). Wir sehen einen Bank-Kredit als letzte Alternative, wenn Eigenkapital, Eigenleistung und die Hilfe von Freunden und Unterstützern ausgeschöpft sind. Mit deiner Hilfe kannst du folgendes erreichen:

  • Du hilfst unser Region
  • Du hilfst Leuten, die Häuser aus natürlichen Ressourcen bauen wollen
  • Du gibst einer kleinen Familie ein gemünliches Zuhause, das sie sich leisten können
  • Du bekommst einen der tollen Perks (z.B. einen 1-wöchigen Urlaub inklusive Touri-Führung)

 

Wann wollen wir das tun?

Nachdem die Finanzierung steht, wollen wir das Haus im September 2016 kaufen. Die Kündigungsfrist unserer alten Wohnung beträgt 3 Monate. Wir werden die Zeit nutzen, uns ein kleines Ofen-Zimmer herzurichten, wo wir den Winter überdauern können. Von dort aus können wir anfangen, am Haus zu arbeiten.

Nach etwa einem Jahr harter Arbeit denken wir, dass das Haus in einem Zustand ist, dass man gut darin leben kann. Ab Sommer 2017 können wir hoffentlich die ersten Urlaubs-Perks erfüllen.

 

Wie kannst du uns noch helfen?


Bist du ein Heimwerker? Willst du uns besuchen und den Boden unter den Zimmern ausschachten? Eine Fußbodenheizung installieren oder eine Lehmwand bauen? Um dich bei uns zu melden, hole den Helfer-Perk (den wir möglichst billig gemacht haben), sodass wir deine E-Mail-Adresse haben, um dir alles weitere zu sagen.

Wenn du die Idee von Umgebindehäusern magst, erzähle es weiter! Sage es deinen Freunden und Nachbarn und mache es uns nach - kauf eines der Häuser und saniere es. Du wirst ein gemütliches Heim haben, das im Sommer kühl und im Winter warm ist.


Umgebindehaus (house with log cabin and half timbering combined)


We are a family of three members: Mother Susanne, father Carl-Philip and son Luke. We are living in a flat inside a concreate panel building.  It is exhausting for my wife to climb up five stories without an elevator (and being pregnant). We just want to get back to nature.

The Oberlausitz (Upper Lusatia) is a region in Saxony located between Germany, Czech Republic and Poland. It is known for a special type of building: The Umgebindehaus. These houses are about 200-500 years old and completely built out of wood, loam and natural stone. A log cabin on the ground level ensures thermal insulation even in deepest winter. A timbering around the log cabin adds additional floors made of half timbering.

Lots of Umgebindehaus homes are in good shape because someone lives in them. But there are also lots of houses that have been abandoned. We want to move into one of these houses and renovate it. We want to keep the original materials as much as possible since they are proven to last hundreds of years.

 

What we want to do

 

Old wooden houses are cozy, but the last time this house was renovated was before WW II. So there is a lot to do to make it a comfortable home again:

     
  • Insert new windows
  • Repair some clay plaster on the facade
  • Add some environment-friendly thermal insulation under the floor (which is raw earth in the moment)
  • Add underfloor heating
  • Modernize electricity
  • Modernize water pipes and toilet (earth closet)

We will be able to buy this house for 20,000 Euro. Our plan is to invest about 60,000 Euro in renovation. So we need 80,000 Euro in total. We set our campaign goal at 25,000 Euro so that we can at least buy the house and some tools to start working.

It is not a problem if we collect more money than we need.. The house has three floors and for the moment, we are only plan to renovate the ground floor. The other floors are reserved for guests and more children.

Why should you support us?

My wife is a full-time mother and I am self-employed --- best conditions to get a loan, right? Also, we don't like the idea of borrowing money and paying interest. We see a bank loan as the last alternative after our own equity, our workforce and the help of friends and supporters.

With your help, we can achieve the following:

  • Help our region by preserving these historic structures
  • Help people who want to use natural resources for constructio
  • Give a small family a cozy home that is affordable
  • You get one of the cool perks we prepared for you (e.g. a 1-week holiday including a tourist guide)
 

When do we want to do it?

After funding, we want to buy that house in September 2016. The period of notice for our old flat is three months. We will use this time to prepare a single room for us to live in during construction. We will use an oven for heat through the winter and start working at the house.

After about a year of hard work we think we will have the house in shape where it is both beautiful and inhabitable. By Summer of 2017 we can fulfill the first holiday perks. 
 

Other ways to help us


Do you love craftsmanship? Do you want to visit us and help us digging out the floor of a chamber or build an underfloor heating or a wall out of clay? Then visit our construction site. If you want to stay in contact with us, take the helper-perk (which we made affordable). We will email you for more details.

Also, if you like the idea of Umgebindehaus, spread the word, tell your friends and neighbors about it and follow our footsteps --- buy one of these houses and renovate it. You will have a cozy, healthy home that is cool in the summer and warm in the winter.

story:
This campaign has ended! Maybe, we will give it a second chance early 2016. To stay informed, go to "contact" and leave us your email! Thank You!


Lesen Sie diesen Text in Deutsch

Organic Farming and Renewable Energy in one Place: Agrophotovoltaics

This project would like to research under which conditions a field can be simultaneously used for organic farming and energy generation using photovoltaics. We call this combination: Agrophotovoltaics.

It should also demonstrate how well PV facilities can protect the plants from the negative effects of the climate change, such as droughts, storm, hail and torrential rain.

Objective

The new facility (350 kWp) in the Burgenland (Austria, Europe) will only have half the usual number of modules, in order to determine whether a 50 per cent incidence of light is sufficient for the economic return on certain sorts of grain and vegetables.

In order to ensure a scientific evaluation of the project, together with the Fraunhofer ISE Institute in Germany, two professors from the University for Natural Resources and Life Sciences (BoKu, Vienna, Austria), an organic farmer and an expert on permaculture could be successfully recruited to accompany the project.

After completion of the research work, which is planned for three years, valuable scientific results will be available, that can be transferred to, or multiplied in arid climates like Northern Africa or Middle East.

We are now banking on your support to finance this research project, because there are no subsidies for photovoltaic green-field plants in Austria. The budget collected will be used to finance the erection of the photovoltaic facility, the work of the organic farmer and the permaculture expert, the research work by the Fraunhofer ISE Institute and the two professors from University for Natural Resources and Life Sciences for three years.

The sub-structure for the photovoltaic facility will be somewhat more expensive, since it has to be erected higher than usual to give enough clearance for tractors.

Crop cultivation under the PV modules

Scientific literature shows that there are plants that deliver an identical or even higher return in partial shade compared to those exposed to direct sunlight. According to our sources this even includes plants such as lettuce, rye or potatoes.

In order to be able to make scientifically relevant statements, the experiments are to run over a longer period (at least three years), in order to have a better understanding of the influence of the weather and the climate. For this, it is necessary to install numerous, different sensors, which continuously and simultaneously measure the weather data (temperature, precipitation and wind), the incidence of light on and under the structure as well as soil data (temperature, carbon content and moistness at different depths) in many positions.

The electricity generated and the food products will be sold and the proceeds reinvested.  However, this will only result in a small contribution to the project financing.

If we do not achieve the funding objective, we will, depending on the volume, erect a smaller PV facility and research fewer plants with our partners. If we get more than our objective, we can conduct more research or even erect a second research facility.


What you give us and what you get
As a perk we will give you our findings: Since many people have a small garden or terrace and can doubly use their own areas in future. Thus it is not a donation, it is an investment in our and your future!

The project is very important, since it is:
•  globally a forerunner.
•  directly relevant for many regions worldwide (like aride regions e.g. Northern Africa, Middle East...)
•  produces organic products and ecological power in parallel.
•  delivers scientific knowledge.
•  can demonstrate how well PV facilities can protect the plants from the negative effects of the climate change, such as droughts, storm, hail and torrential rain.
•  can make regions economically more independent with more self-production of food and power.

The consequences
Every project contains risks. Since Patrick already owns the land, and has appropriate references and the approval to erect a photovoltaic facility, this project has a high probability of implementation. He has already invested his own capital.

However, the facility approved by the authorities is a "normal" facility. It is now a question of submitting the changes to the facility and obtaining the approval of the authorities. If the changes are not approved, we plan to build the approved facility, making minor modifications, so that an approval by the authorities is no longer necessary.

The more support we get from you, the better. So join us and take a look at our perks in the right column.

Our goal is to generate at least 500,000 USD. With this amount we can create a smaller system with only one species of plant. With a total of 1,000,000 USD we would be able to set up a scientifically relevant project with various kind of vegetables and crops.

THANK YOU

story:
Short Summary

Hi, I'm Russell Leidich. In 2010, I released "Jungle Bubble", a YouTube video of my lushly planted 8-gallon fish bowl on the Dangerous Fishbowl channel. Over the next 5 years, it garnered almost half a million views and over a thousand comments, both praise and criticism, for the design. Ultimately, I realized that I had a de facto social responsibility to make something better in response. Junglejar is the culmination of that feedback in conjunction with my own experimentation.

Junglejar offers the low maintenance burden that sophisticated aquarists have come to expect from modern aquariums, but balances this requirement against the waste and expense created by the myriad of overengineered single-use solutions available on the market today. The idea is to create the most elegant encapsulation vessel economically possible, while maximizing reusability and minimizing throwaway technology which would get landfilled at the end of the product life cycle.

One of my earliest reviewers was Aaron Bell, an aspiring entrepreneur and outspoken critic of stupid business ideas. To my delight, he loved the design and decided to sign on as our customer service and marketing guru.

We believe that the use of nonrecyclable and grossly excessive packaging is evidence of selfishness and idiocy. So whenever possible, we plan to reuse manufacturer packaging or clean grocery store boxes to send you your kit. In no event will we cause the manufacture of styrofoam beyond what is available through reuse.

But none of this is about us. It's about you, what gives you peace in your home or workplace, and allows you the freedom to express your own environmental dreams through living art. Embrace your wildness!

What We Need & What You Get

Have a look at the perks. As you'll notice, we have 3 different sizes of Junglejar, and for each, a barebones kit and a full kit. Think of them as different canvasses on which to paint your own interpretation of nature.

We have done everything possible to minimize the amount of funds required, but the manufacturers have given us their bottom line minimum order quantities, hence the minimum funding that we're seeking. Should we fail to reach our goal, no shipping expenses will be incurred, and your funds will be refunded according to standard Indiegogo policy.

The Impact

Imagine the difference we might make if, in thousands of homes and especially  public spaces throughout the world, we were able to display living aquatic nature in 360 degrees of awe-inspiring glory. Ultimately, it's my hope that Junglejar becomes an instrument of environmental policy change, serving as an undeniable testament to the value of our diminishing riparian assets.

Risks & Challenges

There is no challenge greater for us, at the moment, than raising the funds required to pay our manufacturers and deliver your Junglejars in a timely fashion. Beyond that, of course, your own challenge will to be to create a sustainable natural ecosystem, and a work of art in its own right. We plan a series of educational videos on the Dangerous Fishbowl channel to help you accomplish this.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word! Who knows what such living artwork might accomplish. After all, it really does have a life of its own...
story_txt:
Short SummaryHi, I'm Russell Leidich. In 2010, I released "Jungle Bubble", a YouTube video of my lushly planted 8-gallon fish bowl on the Dangerous Fishbowl channel. Over the next 5 years, it garnered almost half a million views and over a thousand comments, both praise and criticism, for the design. Ultimately, I realized that I had a de facto social responsibility to make something better in response. Junglejar is the culmination of that feedback in conjunction with my own experimentation.Junglejar offers the low maintenance burden that sophisticated aquarists have come to expect from modern aquariums, but balances this requirement against the waste and expense created by the myriad of overengineered single-use solutions available on the market today. The idea is to create the most elegant encapsulation vessel economically possible, while maximizing reusability and minimizing throwaway technology which would get landfilled at the end of the product life cycle.One of my earliest reviewers was Aaron Bell, an aspiring entrepreneur and outspoken critic of stupid business ideas. To my delight, he loved the design and decided to sign on as our customer service and marketing guru.We believe that the use of nonrecyclable and grossly excessive 
packaging is evidence of selfishness and idiocy. So whenever possible, 
we plan to reuse manufacturer packaging or clean grocery store boxes to 
send you your kit. In no event will we cause the manufacture of styrofoam beyond what is available through reuse.But none of this is about us. It's about you, what gives you peace in your home or workplace, and allows you the freedom to express your own environmental dreams through living art. Embrace your wildness!
  What We Need & What You GetHave a look at the perks. As you'll notice, we have 3 different sizes of Junglejar, and for each, a barebones kit and a full kit. Think of them as different canvasses on which to paint your own interpretation of nature.We have done everything possible to minimize the amount of funds required, but the manufacturers have given us their bottom line minimum order quantities, hence the minimum funding that we're seeking. Should we fail to reach our goal, no shipping expenses will be incurred, and your funds will be refunded according to standard Indiegogo policy.
  The ImpactImagine the difference we might make if, in thousands of homes and especially  public spaces throughout the world, we were able to display living aquatic nature in 360 degrees of awe-inspiring glory. Ultimately, it's my hope that Junglejar becomes an instrument of environmental policy change, serving as an undeniable testament to the value of our diminishing riparian assets.
  Risks & ChallengesThere is no challenge greater for us, at the moment, than raising the funds required to pay our manufacturers and deliver your Junglejars in a timely fashion. Beyond that, of course, your own challenge will to be to create a sustainable natural ecosystem, and a work of art in its own right. We plan a series of educational videos on the Dangerous Fishbowl channel to help you accomplish this.
  Other Ways You Can HelpPlease help us spread the word! Who knows what such living artwork might accomplish. After all, it really does have a life of its own...

story:
The Story

My son and I are working to protect the sea turtle populations that nest on the pacific coast of Nicaragua, near Puerto Salinas. Our focus is to provide smale scale solutions to problems in Nicaragua, especially those affecting the local ecology and living conditions. We work with the philosophy to help conserve the natural environment and benefit the local communities where we operate.

The area near Puerto Salinas is rich with bio-diversity, including turtle hatching areas going back milennia. But they have been poached for generations for food and income, so we want to change that by buying the eggs from the poachers for the same price and re-nesting the eggs in a secure turtle hatchery. It's a win-win scenario.

We also want to make this self sustaining, so we will start by building 2 cabanas (one room buildings) where visitors can stay. The rental income will be use solely to fund future operations of the hatchery and this hostel.

Over the past year, we've been negotiating with a local resort developer to donate land for a turtle hatchery and hostel on their property. This was the hardest part. In our agreement, they've stipulated that we raise the money needed to build the hatchery and the first two cabanas (the 'hostel') in the first year, and cover all operational costs for the first year.

Once the cabanas are built, they can be rented to visiting backpackers, small groups and families who want a truly unique experience working with the turtles. The rental income will be used solely to hire local staff, buy the eggs from the poachers, build more buildings on the lot, and generally run the operation.

Visitors will be able to help with the turtle hostel (i.e. releasing the turtles), as well as participate in the outdoor and water activities provided by the Playa Tesoro Resort.

What We Need & What You Get

Based on local quotes, we need $17,500 to build the hatchery, 2 cabanas and support building. The first years' operation costs include $1,000 for onsite staff, and $3,500 to buy the eggs from the locals.

We have smaller perks to make you feel good if you cannot visit us, and larger perks if you want to visit us to see the turtles during their hatching season. To really see the excitement of helping in the release of the turtles, watch this video.

By contributing to this campaign, YOU WILL HELP SAVE UPTO 5000 TURTLE EGGS IN THE FIRST YEAR AND PROVIDE A STABLE INCOME FOR NATIVE NICARAGUANS. And you are sending a message that you support the ecology!

If this campaign is really successful, we can start to build another 2 cabanas, install a night camera linked to our website, perform an extensive beach cleanup, improve the planned education center, and add a unique water collection system on the site for the local community (as an alternative to using local stream and waterways).

Frequently Asked Questions

Q: Do you offer a referral program for this campaign?

A: Yes, we do. First contribute to the Backpackers Week (or higher) perk. Then, get 4 or more people to contribute to the same level or higher and you will be entered into one of the two draws for a few week at the hostel.

We have reserved two draws for people participating in this referral program, so the odds of winning are much higher than our open draws.

Here's how to participate:

1. Log into Indiegogo and go to the Turtle Hostel campaign page.

2. Click on the Twitter or Facebook icons to share the campaign via social media OR, click the "link" icon to copy your personal link to share by email, messages or other private communications.

3. Your link is personal and can be traced back to YOU. When someone visits the page through your link and contributes to the campaign, Indiegogo’s system will automatically credit you as the referrer.

4. If four of your friends have contributed to the Turtle Hostel campaign using your link, you will get entered into the closed draw for one week at the Turtle Hostel.

 

Q: How are you connected with Playa Tesoro?

A: We are not connected with the land developer at the Playa Tesoro Resort. Other than what has been stated in this campaign, there is no financial affiliation or overlapping ownership.

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge is simply raising the money. We have firm commitments from the developer for the land, and plenty of local interest in this project.

If we do not raise the money via this campaign, we'll try other fundraising initiatives.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you donate or not, you can still help by spreading the word and sharing with your networks. With this project, you can feel confident that every dollar received from this campaign will be applied to making this project happen.

Share it up!

story:
BdShort Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
We are Dry Goods Refillery from Maplewood, NJ and our dreams are BIGGER and BOLDER than ever! We are now expanding our concept into a second location and will open  New Jersey's FIRST dedicated plastic-free grocery store in Montclair.  This store will offer all the key grocery essentials and categories from dry goods and fresh produce to dairy and fresh-baked breads-- all free of packaging and plastic waste.

Imagine being able to shop for all the following without waste or plastic packaging :

  • beans, grains, rice and pastas
  • cooking oils, honey, syrup and vinegars
  • spices, snacks and cereals
  • bulk coffee and loose leaf teas
  • local eggs, milk, dairy and cheeses
  • fresh farm produce
  • artisanal fresh-baked breads 
  • alternative mylks
  • frozen foods and refrigerated refills (condiments, etc.) 

 

We also will open a store that represents and directly supports the local community. In addition to continuing our support of small, organic farmers, we will expand our offerings through partnerships with several Montclair specialty businesses, including Paper Plane Coffee for bulk coffee beans and Le French Dad Boulangerie for fresh-baked breads. And by highlighting local businesses as much as possible we will also be filling our store with high quality products as sustainably as possible.

We also will carry locally made items prepared foods like pasta sauce, condiments and hummus -- all in returnable, fully sanitized, reusable containers that never get thrown away: a true closed-loop refill system! You simply bring back the empty jar when you're finished and swap it out for a new one. 

We don't want more stuff to throw away in the trash and we don't want our food sources or supply chains to be part of the problem.

Our previous experience has shown that not only is this possible, but that shopping this way provides a successful way to partner with and grow small businesses within the community. A true win-win!

We will build off of our existing experience, but we need YOU and our #refillrevolution community to help us turn our full vision into reality. With this campaign, we are looking to raise $20,000 to properly outfit our shop with:

  • gravity bins -- bulk storage for dried goods (e.g. beans, grains, rice) that allow for contact-free dispensing
  • produce merchandisers -- refrigeration to properly keep loose produce fresh and sold in a way that easily allows customers to access it
  • dairy refrigeration  -- refrigeration for returnable glass milk jugs, farm fresh eggs and other refrigerated essentials

 

Want to see our stretch goals? The more money we raise, the more we can do:

And remember, we're building Dry Goods Refillery to directly support Montclair and the surrounding community. After you donate feel free to contact us and let us know what you want to see most in the shop!

We are so grateful for each and every dollar contributed toward this campaign. To thank you for your support, we're providing a selection of perks including items from our grocery assortment that highlight some of our favorite local and sustainable offerings. 

We appreciate contributions from anyone who believes in a low-waste grocery mission; nevertheless our success is dependent on the support of our local community. Therefore please note that any products in our rewards will be for local pick up only, and arranged only after the end of our fundraising campaign. Shipping worldwide creates a lot of additional waste and negatively contributes to our planet's carbon footprint -- going against our company’s mission. 

If you wish to choose your donation amount or donate without a perk: 

  • DESKTOP: Click the pink "BACK" button at the top of the campaign 
  • MOBILE: Scroll right to the last option on the "perks" bar

PROBLEM: Packaging pollution is a serious problem. Single-use plastics account for 50% of plastics produced and are one of the most common items found in our oceans (NRDC). 

SOLUTION: Dry Goods Refillery will expand upon our existing efforts and eliminate unnecessary plastic packaging for all the items typically purchased in a grocery store. We will offer the option of BYOC (bring your own container) and also a closed-loop system to reuse and replace containers.

_______________________________________________________________

PROBLEM: We have a food waste problem. The average American household wastes over 30% of their food purchased (AAEA) and that waste most likely ends up in a landfill where it generates harmful levels of methane gas, a leading contributor to climate change (EPA). 

SOLUTION: Our store will allow customers to purchase their items by weight, taking as much or as little as they like --  preventing food waste while saving on costs. We also will partner with the locally owned commercial composting service Java's Compost to ensure any waste we incur is properly disposed of and composted.

_______________________________________________________________

PROBLEM: Recycling is not working. Most attempts at recycling are just "wish-cycling." According to the EPA, only 35% of what is placed in the bin actually gets recycled and only 8% of plastics are repurposed into something new. SOLUTION: Our core mission is to eliminate plastic packaging whenever possible.  Any we do obtain will be disposed of properly through our partnership with TerraCycle, a New Jersey company and innovative leader in recycling hard-to-recycle materials.Watch this recent video interview we did at our Maplewood shop to learn more about our family, our story and how fun refilling can be. 

Want to see more of our press coverage? Click here.
