story:
- ABOUT THE PROJECT - 

On March 11th 2011, Fukushima became struck with one of the most devastating energy disasters in human history. Hundreds of thousands of people lost their homes, even today, 8 years later, many remain displaced, and many areas remain heavily contaminated with radioactive material. It strongly impacted the agricultural sector in Fukushima, on which the local economy strongly depended. Many are reluctant to come back after the Great East Japan Earthquake, the Tsunami that followed, and the nuclear accident. 

However, some have stayed to rebuild their communities and are turning Fukushima into a symbolic place for renewable energy. With the support of local residents, grass-root movements have made community projects in renewable energy flourish in Fukushima. Coming together as a community, they have achieved remarkable results. ISEP has worked relentlessly to help these community projects flourish all over Japan. We would like interns to experience first-hand how the people in Fukushima have built their own community power projects and how they are revitalizing the area. Additional funds raised will go towards the development of community power projects in Japan.

During their visit to Fukushima, ISEP interns will visit 2 community power companies: Ai Power and Iitate Denryoku, and Tsuchiyu, who have made impressive results. In addition, interns will stay with locals and hear their stories about Fukushima and what they did to rebuild their region.

Normichi Chiba, founder of Iitate Denryoku together with ISEP interns at Oguni Power plant during their visit in 2018.

- WHAT IS COMMUNITY POWER? -

Community power are power projects where there is a strong engagement of the local community in the power project, and where the local residents are the beneficiaries. Unlike large electric companies, community projects ensure the inclusion and participation of the local community. 

Community power has had prominent examples in Japan and has been an important aspect for introducing renewable energy in Japan. Japan’s history with community power dates back to the 2000's, with one of the prominent examples being in Hokkaido, the North of Japan,where wind turbines were funded by Hokkaido’s people. After the Fukushima accident, community power accelerated, with more than a 1000 community projects in Japan today, with many of them located in the Fukushima area, including Ai Power and Iitate Denryoku. 

In addition, community engagement also ensures that local knowledge is transferred, which is often lost by big developers. ISEP interns will learn more about why local know-how is important in the case of renewable energy.

 

-WHAT WILL THEY DO IN FUKUSHIMA?-

During this trip, interns will learn first-hand how community projects were developed and how communities work together for a common cause.

The visit will last 3 days, and they will visit Iitate Power, Ai Power, learning about both community solar energy and community geothermal energy. In addition, the interns will have the opportunity to experience the daily activities of local Fukushima farmers, and hear about how they got through the Fukushima disaster, as well as a hot spring hotel near the Tsuchiyu hydroelectric plant and the Tsuchiyu geothermal power plant. The schedule mentioned is tentative, and the activities might change order, depending on the availability of the local organizations in Fukushima. 

Day 1:

Travel from Tokyo to Fukushima

Fukushima is located around 300 kilometers (approx. 185 miles) from Tokyo. Interns will do the trip by train, which brings them to Fukushima in less than 2 hours. 

Tsuchiyu Binary geothermal plant and Sansuiso Hotel’s small hydro

In Tsuchiyu, interns will learn about the binary geothermal plant which the locals use. This is a sustainable and clean way to generate energy. Japan is famous for its many natural hot springs, which can be used to generate renewable energy, but locals are concerned this will contaminate the hot spring water. However, in this case, the pump has no negative impact on water quality. interns will learn how this is possible. The binary geothermal plant can have an output up to 400 kilowatts, which is a substantial amount for the community.

Then, the interns will be able to stay at the Sansuiso hotel in the Tsuchiyu area, which uses in addition a small hydroelectricity plant and which can generate up to 140 kilowatts.

ISEP interns in 2018 in front of the Tsuchiyu Geothermal Power plant.

Day 2:

Visit of Ai Power and the Oguni Power plant: 

Ai Power has a very strict policy to only include local stakeholders in their project. In the case of the Oguni Power plant, Ai Power’s largest solar plant, eight local governments, two local companies, five local banks and 47 residents were involved. Here, interns will learn about community involvement and local know-how in Fukushima’s energy projects. 

Image taken on last year's visit, view on the Oguni power plant from Oguni University.

Visit to "Oguni University":

The Aizu Electric Power Company does not only build power plants, but they also want to raise awareness of the benefits and importance of renewable energies among the general public and children. Therefore, they established the Oguni University right next to the solar park and offer tours to the Oguni Power Plant for everyone interested in it. The ISEP interns will also visit the Oguni university and learn more about renewables. Oguni University is not an official university, but the learning center is nicknamed as "Oguni Univerity". 

ISEP interns at Oguni University, during their visit in 2018.

Stay at the local Fukushima agricultural center and meeting with local farmer's about their experience after the nuclear disaster.

After a day of learning about renewable energy, ISEP interns will have the opportunity to stay with a local family in Fukushima at a farm. Here, they will have the opportunity to learn about how each family was affected by the Great East Japan Earthquake, the tsunami and the nuclear leak at the Fukushima Daiichi reactor. Although 8 years has past, since the Fukushima disaster, the Fukushima region is far from having entirely recovered. Apart from the nuclear contamination, many areas were entirely destroyed because of the earthquake and tsunami. An estimated 25 million ton of debris and rubble was created, destroying houses, cutting access to electricity and water. 

Day 3:

Visit to Iitate Denryoku

Iitate village is located about 39 km northwest of Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power plant. In Iitate, ISEP interns will learn about the impact of Fukushima on the Iitate village and the response of local residents. In particular, they will visit Iitate Denryoku where they will learn about community power. 

Even after 8 years after the nuclear disaster, many parts of Iitate remain contaminated with nuclear waste, and the land can often not be used for agricultural purposed. Especially the forests and areas removed from resident housing are still to be decontaminated. ISEP interns will learn about the impact of radiation and the rules of the decontamination processes.

ISEP interns in Iitate together with Norimichi Chiba, during their visit in 2018.

Return to Tokyo and continuing support to Iitate Denryoku and Ai Power

At the end of the third day, the interns will return to Tokyo and reflect about their trip. Interns will in addition write a report which reflects their experience and what they have learned. In addition, ISEP staff and our interns will help both Iitate Denryoku and Aizu Denryoku with translations or other services as a contribution to their efforts to make renewable energy flourish in Fukushima. 

 

- THE STORY BEHIND AI POWER -

Ai Power was established in 2013 and is located in Aizuwakamatsu in order to make Fukushima a self-sufficient region using renewable energy and to eliminate nuclear energy. 

Many local businesses in Fukushima were strongly affected by the Fukushima Nuclear disaster. The Yamatogawa Sake Brewery has been no exception. Sato Yauemon’s family has been running the Yamatogawa sake brewery for generations and is considered an important figure in the local region. 

Website: https://aipower.co.jp

Sato Yauemon, founder of Ai Power, photo's retrieved from http://www.energy-democracy.jp/751 and https://greenz.jp/2016/11/24/aizu_denryoku/ 

Depending on rice and clean water resources from the region, Yauemon became strongly concerned with the impact that the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster on the region. Taking his responsibility as a business leader in the region, Yauemon decided to start Ai Power together with the local community in Aizuwakamatsu. 

Ai Power's Model for community power, retrieved from https://aipower.co.jp/companysummary 

Last year, ISEP Interns Visited both Oguni University and the Oguni Solar power plant. The Oguni solar plant is Ai Power’s first megasolar project and has a capacity of 1000 kilowatts. Such a large energy plant is generally only operated by large energy companies and is an impressive achievement for community power.

ISEP interns visiting the Oguni power plant in 2018.

Today, Ai power’s energy production can generate close to 6000 kilowatts in capacity, on the map below, you can see a number of Ai Power’s projects. As you can see, Ai Power has worked relentlessly to increase Fukushima’s energy independency and provide clean energy to the citizens of Fukushima.

Ai power projects, photo retrieved from https://aipower.co.jp/business 

- THE STORY BEHIND IITATE DENRYOKU -

         

Iitate Denryoku was started in 2014 by Norimichi Chiba after the Fukushima accident. Chiba used to work in a company in Tokyo, but after the devastation from Fukushima, he went back to his home region and to help the Iitate community to establish its own community power project. The aim of Iitate Denryoku is to establish a “Stadtwerk”, a municipal power utility.

Website: http://iitatepower.jp/works/index.html  

Iitate Village and the Fukushima Nuclear Accident:

Iitate village, where Iitate Denryoku is located, has been part of the direct evacuation zone from the Fukushima Nuclear Accident. Even today, a large part of Iitate is part of the restricted area, and residents are not allowed to live there and parts of the region cannot be used for agriculture. Instead, renewable energy projects are being constructed through community power projects.

Below, you can see a map showing the areas most affected by nuclear radiation and the areas where people will be able to live again soon, those where you can't live yet and those where you can't stay long. As can be seen on the map, Iitate Village is in the direct contamination zone. 

 

Map retrieved from: http://fukushimaontheglobe.com/the_earthquake_a... 

Iitate Projects:

Solar panels from Iitate Denryoku, pictures retrieved from http://iitatepower.jp/works/index.html 

 

Iitate Denryoku currently has 42 operational plants, from which 14 are solar sharing projects and another 22 projects are currently being developed. 

So far Iitate Denryoku has made the following projects:

- Solar power

- Solar sharing, combining agriculture and solar energy

Recently, Iitate Denryoku has been working on Solar Sharing projects, combining agriculture and solar energy, in the areas of Fukushima where agriculture has been permitted. Agro-solar combines the agricultural fields with crops and solar panels. In this case, solar panels are installed above the fields, while permitting enough sunlight to penetrate the fields, as can be seen from the image below. Such projects allow to increase renewable energy capacity without taking away agricultural land, highly desirable in Japan where there is a high population density. 

Read more about Iitate here: https://medium.com/thebeammagazine/solar-sharin... 

Solar sharing initiative in Fukushima.

 

 

 

- WHY IS THIS PROJECT IMPORTANT? -

- WHY CROWDFUNDING? -

The Fukushima Disaster and growing evidence of climate change are showing that our current energy system is broken. We need to make the transition to a safe and sustainable system. Too often we think that we cannot have any impact, but community projects, such as the ones our interns will visit, are evidence of how citizen participation has an impact. 

This trip leaves a lasting impact on how our interns perceive renewable energy projects. It also encourages them, to take this knowledge home and share it in their home countries or in their future jobs, as many of our interns work in climate and energy related industries. 

We are using crowdfunding for this project, as we believe that as many as people as possible should be able to support these projects. As community power is a community effort, we believe that raising funds to educate our interns is to be equally a community effort.

 

- ABOUT ISEP -

Who are we?

The Institute for Sustainable Energy Policies (ISEP) was founded in 2000 by Tetsunari Iida and we are located in Tokyo, Japan. Our focus is on promoting renewable energy in Japan and across the globe. We work on a large variety of projects, including providing consultancy services to local communities to develop energy independence, advocacy to Japanese government official, as well as assisting with the development of community projects. In addition, ISEP develops quality research and publishes the Energy Chart, which illustrates Japan energy data. 

We have a global network, and frequently work on projects with other countries. Last year we worked with the Danish government on biomass and worked with Mali Folkecenter, an NGO from Mali, on solar power . We have also been part in the global community power conferences.

About the ISEP Interns:

Each year, we welcome interns from around the globe. At ISEP they learn about energy policies, initiatives and get an insight in the real-life challenges of the energy sector, in particular in Japan. This year alone, we have had interns from Germany, Australia, Bulgaria, Belgium, France, UK, Japan and China. We offer them the opportunity to directly work with us on projects, and we continuously benefit from the knowledge they bring from their home countries. 

ISEP’s involvement in community power:

ISEP has worked with numerous community power projects in Japan, and has closely collaborated with Danish initiatives, such as the Samsoe Academy. Some of the examples are both Iitate Denryoku and Ai Power, but also the Hokkaido Green Fund, and the Community Power Association of Japan. 

To find more information about ISEP, please visit our website: https://www.isep.or.jp/en/

 

- COST BREAKDOWN -

The ideal target is to reach 3040 USD. 

With each target reached, we will be able to send an additional intern. Please see the details of the cost breakdown below. Prices below, are displayed in US Dollars:

* Tsuchiyu Onsen uses a hydroelectric plant, to show support to this initiative, ISEP interns stay at this hot spring hotel. In addition, to show the voluntary support of our interns, 50% of the fee is paid by the interns themselves to stay here.  

** To thank the local Fukushima community power projects, ISEP will offer a free service to them in collaboration with the interns, such as publishing an article or providing an English translation for them. In addition, remaining funds which are not used for the trip will be used towards the development of community power projects in Japan.

- TESTIMONIALS -

Over the years, ISEP has sent many of its interns to community projects in Japan, including international interns. Last year, 3 interns were sent to Fukushima with a similar visit to the one that the interns will do this year. Their experience shows how Fukushima has impacted not only Japan but countries around the globe.

 

- ABOUT THE INTERNS -

This year, we would like to send an international group of 6 interns to the Fukushima area, and spread the word about community power around the globe. We have gathered what some of our interns have to say about why they would like to go to Fukushima and learn about community power. 

 

 

- THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT -

Throughout the crowdfunding process, we will provide you with update on our progress. In addition, once our interns have gone to Fukushima, we will make a report with pictures and share it with our supporters. 

Please support us by sharing this project with your network, the further we reach the more impact we will have! If you have any further questions, please do not hesitate to contact us. 

https://www.isep.or.jp/en/

https://www.facebook.com/isepjapan/

https://www.youtube.com/user/ISEPJAPAN

https://twitter.com/isepjapan

Many are reluctant to come back after the Great East Japan Earthquake, the Tsunami that followed, and the nuclear accident. However, some have stayed to rebuild their communities and are turning Fukushima into a symbolic place for renewable energy. With the support of local residents, grass-root movements have made community projects in renewable energy flourish in Fukushima. Coming together as a community, they have achieved remarkable results. ISEP has worked relentlessly to help these community projects flourish all over Japan. story:
Haz click aquí para Español!

In a nutshell…

If adventure is that idea of doing just one thing differently than you would have done before, then why not offer that opportunity to everyone who wants to seek it? Alihuen’s Accessibility Trail is a reminder that we are all capable of seeking something beyond ourselves.

Regardless of age, ability, or capacity, Alihuen’s Accessibility Trail offers just that. The trail blends the rare beauty of Chiloe (Chile’s “Magic Island”) with the accessibility and inclusivity rarely found within many of Chile’s natural parks.
The Alihuen ecofarm is built on a foundation of sustainability, education, and community outreach, which has created a new standard for reforestation and permaculture within Chile (and abroad, too!).

In doing so, we’re working to create a local movement powered by local and international supporters alike that brings to life environmental education, organic farming, water conservation, and ecotourism in Chile.

So, in 2016, we’ll expand our programming to be more inclusive with Alihuen’s Accessibility Trail, which aims to disable the label of adventure and redefine what access to the outdoors means…for everyone.

About Us

The Family

Jeroen, Grecia, Gabriel & Tamara
Jeroen Beuckels is an award-winning permaculture and reforestation advocate, trained chef, father of 2, and co-founder of Alihuen. Originally from Belgium, his love for the outdoors (and sharing them) began with food, and having worked and trained in 7 countries, Alihuen was the next logical step. Eco-farming and ecotourism allow him to combine his love for being in nature, growing, preparing, and sharing good food, and ultimately preserving the environment through the planting of native trees on a large scale.

Grecia Maldonado Barria is a modern artisan, mother of 2, and co-founder of Alihuen. A Chilote (native of Chiloé, Chile) by birth, her woven crafts incorporate traditional Chilote patterns as well as designs of her own inspiration, drawing from nature to use native plant fibers and recycled (found) objects both from the forest and the sea. An advocate for women-driven micro-businesses, Grecia began her love affair with the loom about 7 years ago, and has since participated in exhibitions, workshops, and fairs throughout Chile, where she displays her own craft as well as imparts these skills to generations young and old.

The Farm


Located in the Chepu region of Chiloé, Chile’s “Magic Island” at the north end of Chilean Patagonia, we practice and teach conservation, permaculture, organic agriculture and ecotourism at Alihuen. Through these sustainable approaches to land management, we are returning exhausted pasture land to its native abundance as a thriving forest.
Our goal with the farm is to one day reconnect the forests of northern Chiloé with the large forested areas of the Chepu River and the Chiloé National Park to the south. In the past 7 years, we have planted about 22,000 native trees in an effort to reforest the “lost” forest and connect isolated forest patches to the adjacent national park; creating passages for wildlife.

The Community

From all over the world, the Alihuen community now includes a family of individuals from 15 countries, many different backgrounds and cultures, and multiple interests and characteristics.
15 countries

7 projects
10 years lapsed
9 partnerships

Our community isn’t limited just to the volunteers who come to us through the World Wide Organization for Organic Farming (WWOOF) and WorkAway, but also through international and national organizations including WikingerReisen, FairChile, the Trekking Chile Foundation, the Organization of Forestry Engineers for the Native Forest (AIFBN), Chile’s National Forest Service (CONAF), and the International Dendrology Society.

What unites the community that has grown around Alihuen is an interest in learning and spreading the key themes behind permaculture and sustainability. Using their various skills and talents, these volunteers have each left their mark on Alihuen to make it what it is today.

What Will the Money Do?


We will be conducting this campaign in stages, due to the long-term and on-going nature of this project. As stages are completed here on Indiegogo, we will be able to update donors on the progress of the project and where the money of future stages will go. To give donors an idea of where their money will go now and in the future, the following steps break down our budget.

Here’s how we’ll spend the $23,000:

$11,000: Eco-friendly trailblazing (literally). We’ll buy treated materials for the path, and work with WWOOF and Work Away volunteers that are a critical part of Alihuen to actually build the trail.
$9,500: Production of 16 “experience panels” describing the flora, fauna, and ecosystem surrounding the trail, these will be available in Braille, English, and Spanish.
$1,500: Wheelchair accessible toilets
$1,000: Prize production costs - buying materials for the handmade local crafts and promotion material like eco-friendly printed postcards.



Español

En una palabra…

Si el turismo de aventura es la idea de hacer una cosa diferente de lo que había hecho antes, ¿por qué no ofrecer la oportunidad para todos los que quieren buscarlo? Alihuen Sendero Accesible es un recordatorio de que todos somos capaces de buscar algo más allá de nosotros mismos.

Sin importar la edad, habilidad o capacidad, Alihuen Sendero Accesible ofrece precisamente eso. El sendero mezcla la belleza de Chiloé con la accesibilidad y la inclusión que rara vez se encuentran en muchos de los parques naturales de Chile. La granja ecológica Alihuen se construye sobre la base de la sostenibilidad, educación y extensión a la comunidad, y ha creado un nuevo estándar para la re-forestación y la permacultura en Chile (y en el extranjero, también!)

Al hacerlo, estamos trabajando para crear un movimiento local impulsado por los partidarios locales e internacionales que dan vida a la educación del medio ambiente, la agricultura ecológica, la conservación del agua y el eco-turismo en Chile.

Así, en 2016, vamos a ampliar nuestras actividades con el Sendero Accesible, que tiene como objetivo desactivar la etiqueta de aventura y redefinir lo que el acceso a actividades al aire libre significa ... para todos.


Sobre nosotros

La Familia

Jeroen, Grecia, Gabriel & Tamara
Jeroen Beuckels es chef, agricultor, padre de 2, promotor de re-forestaciones y co-fundador de Alihuen. Originario de Bélgica, su amor por la naturaleza (y compartirla) comenzó con la comida y después de haber trabajado en 7 países, Alihuen era el siguiente paso lógico.
La agricultura ecológica y el turismo sustentable le permita combinar su amor por estar en la naturaleza, preparar y compartir una buena comida y en última instancia, preservar el medio ambiente a través de la plantaciones de árboles nativos a gran escala.

Grecia Maldonado Barria es una artesana moderna, madre de 2, y Chilota (nativa de Chiloé) por nacimiento. Sus tejidos incorporan patrones tradicionales chilotes, así como diseños de su propia inspiración, dibuja la naturaleza usando fibras de plantas nativas y recicla objetos, tanto del bosque y el mar.
Partidario de micro-empresas conducidas por mujeres, Grecia comenzó su historia de amor con el telar hace unos 7 años, y desde entonces ha participado en exposiciones, talleres y ferias a lo largo de Chile. Muestra su propio trabajo, así como enseña estas habilidades para generaciones de jóvenes y adultos.

La Granja

Situado en la localidad de Chepu, en la Isla Grande de Chiloé, practicamos y enseñamos la conservación, la permacultura, la agricultura orgánica y el eco-turismo. A través de estos enfoques sostenibles para la gestión de la tierra, estamos volviendo pastizales agotados a su origen nativo como un floreciente bosque.

Nuestro objetivo con la granja es que un día vuelva a conectar los bosques del norte de Chiloé con las grandes zonas boscosas del río Chepu y el Parque Nacional Chiloé, al sur. En los últimos 8 años, hemos plantado cerca de 22.000 árboles nativos en un esfuerzo para reforestar el bosque "perdido" y conectar los parches aislados de bosque al parque nacional adyacente. Con este trabajo creamos corredores para la fauna silvestre.

La Comunidad


De todas partes del mundo, la comunidad Alihuen incluye ahora una familia de personas de 15 países, diferentes orígenes y culturas,  múltiples intereses y características.

15 paises

7 proyectos
10 años pasados
9 asociaciones

Nuestra comunidad no se limita solo a los voluntarios que vienen a nosotros a través del World Wide Opportunities on Organic Farms (WWOOF) y Workaway, sino también a través de organizaciones internacionales y nacionales, incluyendo Wikinger Reisen, Fairchile, Fundación TrekkingChile, la Agrupación de Ingenieros Forestales por el Bosque Nativo, el Servicio Forestal Nacional de Chile (CONAF), y la Sociedad Internacional de Dendrología.

Lo que une a la comunidad que ha crecido alrededor Alihuen es un interés en el aprendizaje y la difusión de los temas clave detrás de la permacultura y la sustentabilidad. Usando sus diversas habilidades y talentos, estos voluntarios han dejado cada uno su huella en Alihuen para que sea lo que es hoy.

¿Qué vamos a hacer con el dinero?


Llevaremos a cabo esta campaña en etapas, debido al largo plazo y la complejidad de este proyecto.
A medida que se completan las etapas en Indiegogo, vamos a ser capaces de informar los donantes sobre el progreso del proyecto y el destino del dinero de las futuras etapas.
Para dar una idea en que su dinero irá ahora y en el futuro, les mostramos nuestro presupuesto.

Así es como vamos a utilizar los $ 23,000:

$11,000: Construcción del sendero. Vamos a comprar los materiales para el camino y trabajaremos con voluntarios de WWOOF y Workaway.  Ellos/as serán una parte crítica en Alihuen para la construcción de este sendero.
$ 9,500: La producción de 16 paneles interpretativos que describen la flora, la fauna, y el ecosistema que rodea el sendero, éstas estarán disponibles en Braille, Inglés, y Español.
$ 1.500: Baños (aseos) accesibles para personas en silla de ruedas
$ 1,000: Costos de producción - la compra de materiales para la artesanía local y la imprenta de tarjetas postales promocionales (son de una imprenta que trabaja solamente con productos amigables para el medio ambiente).
story_txt:
Haz click aquí para Español!In a nutshell…If adventure is that idea of doing just one thing differently than you would have done before, then why not offer that opportunity to everyone who wants to seek it? Alihuen’s Accessibility Trail is a reminder that we are all capable of seeking something beyond ourselves.Regardless of age, ability, or capacity, Alihuen’s Accessibility Trail offers just that. The trail blends the rare beauty of Chiloe (Chile’s “Magic Island”) with the accessibility and inclusivity rarely found within many of Chile’s natural parks.The Alihuen ecofarm is built on a foundation of sustainability, education, and community outreach, which has created a new standard for reforestation and permaculture within Chile (and abroad, too!).In doing so, we’re working to create a local movement powered by local and international supporters alike that brings to life environmental education, organic farming, water conservation, and ecotourism in Chile.So, in 2016, we’ll expand our programming to be more inclusive with Alihuen’s Accessibility Trail, which aims to disable the label of adventure and redefine what access to the outdoors means…for everyone.About UsThe FamilyJeroen, Grecia, Gabriel & TamaraJeroen Beuckels is an award-winning permaculture and reforestation advocate, trained chef, father of 2, and co-founder of Alihuen. Originally from Belgium, his love for the outdoors (and sharing them) began with food, and having worked and trained in 7 countries, Alihuen was the next logical step. Eco-farming and ecotourism allow him to combine his love for being in nature, growing, preparing, and sharing good food, and ultimately preserving the environment through the planting of native trees on a large scale.
Grecia Maldonado Barria is a modern artisan, mother of 2, and co-founder of Alihuen. A Chilote (native of Chiloé, Chile) by birth, her woven crafts incorporate traditional Chilote patterns as well as designs of her own inspiration, drawing from nature to use native plant fibers and recycled (found) objects both from the forest and the sea. An advocate for women-driven micro-businesses, Grecia began her love affair with the loom about 7 years ago, and has since participated in exhibitions, workshops, and fairs throughout Chile, where she displays her own craft as well as imparts these skills to generations young and old.

The Farm


Located in the Chepu region of Chiloé, Chile’s “Magic Island” at the north end of Chilean Patagonia, we practice and teach conservation, permaculture, organic agriculture and ecotourism at Alihuen. Through these sustainable approaches to land management, we are returning exhausted pasture land to its native abundance as a thriving forest.
Our goal with the farm is to one day reconnect the forests of northern Chiloé with the large forested areas of the Chepu River and the Chiloé National Park to the south. In the past 7 years, we have planted about 22,000 native trees in an effort to reforest the “lost” forest and connect isolated forest patches to the adjacent national park; creating passages for wildlife.
The Community

From all over the world, the Alihuen community now includes a family of individuals from 15 countries, many different backgrounds and cultures, and multiple interests and characteristics.
15 countries7 projects10 years lapsed9 partnerships
Our community isn’t limited just to the volunteers who come to us through the World Wide Organization for Organic Farming (WWOOF) and WorkAway, but also through international and national organizations including WikingerReisen, FairChile, the Trekking Chile Foundation, the Organization of Forestry Engineers for the Native Forest (AIFBN), Chile’s National Forest Service (CONAF), and the International Dendrology Society.
What unites the community that has grown around Alihuen is an interest in learning and spreading the key themes behind permaculture and sustainability. Using their various skills and talents, these volunteers have each left their mark on Alihuen to make it what it is today.
What Will the Money Do?


We will be conducting this campaign in stages, due to the long-term and on-going nature of this project. As stages are completed here on Indiegogo, we will be able to update donors on the progress of the project and where the money of future stages will go. To give donors an idea of where their money will go now and in the future, the following steps break down our budget.Here’s how we’ll spend the $23,000:$11,000: Eco-friendly trailblazing (literally). We’ll buy treated materials for the path, and work with WWOOF and Work Away volunteers that are a critical part of Alihuen to actually build the trail. $9,500: Production of 16 “experience panels” describing the flora, fauna, and ecosystem surrounding the trail, these will be available in Braille, English, and Spanish.$1,500: Wheelchair accessible toilets$1,000: Prize production costs - buying materials for the handmade local crafts and promotion material like eco-friendly printed postcards.

story:
Short Summary


Plastic wastes are not biodegradable, thus even after land-filled, plastics last over a hundred years, contaminating the surface of the earth endangering the inland ecology and creating gabage patches in the Oceans, devastating marine life as well. 

Dioxins are considered to be one of the most dangerous poisons in the environment, generated by burning chlorinated hydrocarbons like waste plastics in the incinerators. Dioxins are suspected to cause cancer, also cause severe reproductive and developmental problems, and damage the immune and hormonal systems.

Waste plastics are high molecular polymers hence when heated excessively, pyrolyzed to low molecular gas and vapors which condense to oil by cooling. Plastoil is diesel like oil converted from waste plastics by catalytic-pyrolysis process.

Obviously plastic-to-oil project is the best solution to prevent massive Dioxin generation from the incinerators worldwide. It was a policy to develop a practical plastic-to-oil process in the past decade, but all the projects ended up in fruitless results. Existing local plastic-to-oil facilities reveals serious drawbacks;

1) Inefficiency in safety system, causing repeated fire hazards and explosion, threats safety of the operators and the facility.

2)  Low yield outputs excessive residue built-up which is scraped out manually from the pyrolyzer, exposing operators to toxication.

3)  Gas leakage and combustion without neutralization and recycling, seriously pollutes the environment.

Consequently, local incinerators kept on burning waste plastics, despite the risk of Dioxin generation. Millions of tons per year of waste plastics are fed to the incinerators in Korea alone, overloading the costly Dioxin emission control systems.

At an Exhibition, in 2002, I happen to learn that waste plastics could be converted to oil by applying my professional expertise, which inspired me to develop the plastic-to-oil process to recycle waste plastics to valuable oil and to prevent generation of Dioxins. I took on  chemical engineering career, since I graduated Seoul National University in 1972, joined fine chemical company, leading agricultural chemical projects as Project Manager, founded Duretek Inc. in 1995, an engineering company engaged in waste treatment and recycling projects, as CTO to present. (www.dure.com)

I devoted myself in the development of plastic-to-oil process ever since, by starting a bench scale test, Plastoil pilot plant was constructed in Icheon(2004) and consequently in Ilsan(2010). Adopting 40 years of specialty experiences, based on insight into the fail-safe system, determined to achieve State-of-the-Art process, ensuring operators' safety, preventing pollution, and commitment to save the ecology, fail-safe nitrogen sealed, fully automated continuous, SCADA controlled, Plastics Catalytic-pyrolysis Recycling(PCR) process was developed. (Registered Patent KP1180580 2012)



 PCR process features three unique, outstanding performances comparison to the existing unpractical plastic-to-oil process;

1)  Fail-safe system comprised of nitrogen-sealed auto-feeding system, seals off oxygen from entering and keeps hazardous gas from leaking out the process, aided by SCADA control system, ensures total safety of the operators and the facilities.

2)  Yield of Plastoil, conforming to GRM2101 KS specification, upgraded by re-pyrolyzing the separated wax, adopting its unique catalytic-pyrolysis process achieves 80%.

3)   Chlorine contaminants in the gas generated by the pyrolysis process is quenched in the gas scrubber and neutralized, fully recycled to self-suffice the fuel consumption without polluting the atmosphere.

The prototype Plastoil plant will be installed to evaluate and certify the performance of the PCR process, to acquire the official approval, which would motivate commercial scale Plastoil projects to be launched by the local provinces to convert up to one million tons per year of waste plastics in Korea. Furthermore tens of millions of tons per year of waste plastics eventually, would be converted to oil worldwide, to clean-up the floating island of waste plastics in the Oceans and to help bring Dioxin free World to reality. 















What We Need & What You Get



The treating capacity of the prototype Plastoil plant is 50 kg of waste plastics per hour and the cost of the project is $500,000-. It would take about three months to fabricate and install the equipment and three months to test run, optimizing and commissioning, to confirm the safety of the operators and pollution control performances, evaluated and certified  to acquire official approval.



If the funding goal is not met, the treating capacity of the prototype could be reduced to match the fund, within tolerable level.



$10 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our website’s Hall of Donor page.

$25 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our website’s Hall of Donor page.

 Global Plastoil Membership Certificate will be mailed to you.

$50 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our website’s Hall of Donor page.

Global Plastoil Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Medal of Honor will be delivered to you.

$100 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our website’s Hall of Donor page.

Global Plastoil Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Medal of Honor, Global Plastoil Member’s T-shirt will be delivered to you.

$300 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our website’s Hall of Donor page.

Global Plastoil Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Medal of Honor, Global Plastoil Member’s pair T-shirts will be delivered to you.

$500 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our website’s Hall of Donor page.

Global Plastoil Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Medal of Honor, Global Plastoil Member’s T-shirt, Dioxin Free World Campaign Cap will be delivered to you.

$1,000  Perk - Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our website’s Hall of Donor page.

Dioxin Free World Medal of Honor, Global Plastoil Member’s T-shirt, Dioxin Free World Campaign Cap, Global Plastoil Honor Membership Certificate will be delivered to you.

$5,000 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a Dioxin free World.  Your name will be inscribed on our website’s Hall of Donor page.

Global Plastoil Member’s T-shirt, Dioxin Free World Campaign Cap, Global Plastoil Honor Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Plaque of Honor will be delivered to you.

$10,000 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our website’s Hall of Donor page.

Global Plastoil Member’s T-shirt, Dioxin Free World Campaign Cap, Global Plastoil Honor Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Plaque of Honor will be delivered to you.

Just arrive at Incheon International Airport, Korea, we invite you to 3 nights stay in prestigious hotel in Seoul including meals and domestic transportation, Guest of Honor at the Dedication Day Ceremony of the world first Plastoil Plant and reception party.

$50,000 Perk - Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our website’s Hall of Donor page.

Global Plastoil Member’s T-shirt, Dioxin Free World Campaign Cap, Global Plastoil Honor Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Plaque of Honor will be delivered to you.

 Just arrive at Incheon International Airport, Korea, we invite you to  6 nights stay in  prestigious hotel in Seoul, Jeju Island and spiritual Temple Stay at a thousand year old buddhist temple,  including meals and domestic transportation,  Guest of Honor at the Dedication Day Ceremony of the world first Plastoil Plant and reception party.



The Impact


There are no tolerable emission levels for Dioxins, which are one of the most toxic chemicals existing on earth, owing to the resistance to degradation, accumulated in the environment through food chain, causing severe disadvantages to the human health and natural ecology, even with a minimal emission level.



Organic wastes other than waste plastics also cause Dioxin emission when incinerated, but most of them could be composted to give fertilizers for farming or decomposed in the land-fill, whereas waste plastics could not be land-filled because they resist decomposition, which make waste plastics to be the major source of Dioxin generation in the incinerators. Worldwide Plastoil projects will convert waste plastics to oil, to prevent incineration of waste plastics, to minimize the Dioxin generation all around the world to save the environment. 



There are no other practical measures to eliminate the millions of tons of waste plastics contained in the garbage patches in the Oceans. 

Plastoil Salvage Vessel equiped with Plastoil unit launched to the garbage patches in the Oceans,  would be able to convert the millions of tons of waste plastics to millions of barrels of oil, in situ, self sufficing not only  the fuel for the voyage but also to account for the cost to clean-up the coastlines of the contaminated islands.




Risks & Challenges


Plastics pyrolysis process is a highly hazardous process and maximum safety precautions are required for the safe operation of the Plastoil plants. PCR process, fail-safe nitrogen sealed, fully automated continuous,  SCADA control system is developed to ensure safety of the operators and the facility, eliminating any chances of irreversible disaster.

Intensive drill and precautions are also required for the operators to be ready for the confrontation of an unforeseeable disasters. Crisis techniques are mastered by years of in situ experiences of confronting series of life risking critical experiences as project manager in fine chemical process plants and development projects.

Plastoil plants adopting State-of-the-Art PCR process always guarantee maximum safety of the operators and the facility and minimize the contamination of the environment.






Other Ways You Can Help

You can always help prevent generation of Dioxins by expelling usage of expendable containers to reduce plastics and film wastes in everyday life and save the environment.

pilot plant was constructed in Icheon(2004) and consequently in Ilsan(2010). Adopting 40 years of specialty experiences, based on insight into the fail-safe system, determined to achieve State-of-the-Art process,
ensuring operators' safety, preventing pollution, and commitment to save the ecology, fail-safe nitrogen sealed, fully
automated continuous, SCADA controlled, Plastics Catalytic-pyrolysis Recycling(PCR) process
was developed. (Registered Patent KP1180580 2012)



 PCR process features three
unique, outstanding performances comparison to the existing unpractical plastic-to-oil
process;

1)  Fail-safe system comprised of nitrogen-sealed
auto-feeding system, seals off oxygen from entering and keeps hazardous gas
from leaking out the process, aided by SCADA control system, ensures total
safety of the operators and the facilities.

2)  Yield of
Plastoil, conforming to GRM2101 KS specification, upgraded by re-pyrolyzing the
separated wax, adopting its unique catalytic-pyrolysis process achieves 80%.
3)   Chlorine
contaminants in the gas generated by the pyrolysis process is quenched in
the gas scrubber and neutralized, fully recycled to self-suffice the fuel
consumption without polluting the atmosphere.
The prototype Plastoil plant will be installed to evaluate and certify the performance of the PCR
process, to acquire the official approval, which would motivate commercial scale
Plastoil projects to be launched by the local provinces to convert up to one million tons
per year of waste plastics in Korea. Furthermore tens of millions of tons per year of
waste plastics eventually, would be converted to oil worldwide, to clean-up the floating island of waste plastics in the Oceans and to help bring
Dioxin free World to reality. 


































What We Need & What You Get

 

The treating capacity of the prototype Plastoil plant is 50 kg of waste plastics per hour and the cost of the project is $500,000-. It would take about three months to fabricate and install the equipment and three months to test run, optimizing and commissioning, to confirm the safety of the operators and pollution control performances, evaluated and certified  to acquire official approval.




 If the funding goal is not met, the treating capacity of the prototype could be reduced to match the fund, within tolerable level.






$10 Perk -  Your precious commitment
initiates a tide of change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our
website’s Hall of Donor page.
$25 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of
change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our
website’s Hall of Donor page.
 Global Plastoil Membership Certificate will
be mailed to you.
$50 Perk -  Your precious commitment
initiates a tide of change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our
website’s Hall of Donor page.
Global Plastoil Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Medal of Honor will be
delivered to you.
$100 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of
change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our
website’s Hall of Donor page.
Global Plastoil Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Medal of Honor, Global Plastoil Member’s T-shirt will be
delivered to you.

$300 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our website’s Hall of Donor page.
Global Plastoil Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Medal of Honor, Global Plastoil Member’s pair T-shirts will be delivered to you.
$500 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a
Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our
website’s Hall of Donor page.
Global Plastoil Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Medal of Honor, Global Plastoil Member’s T-shirt, Dioxin Free World Campaign Cap will be
delivered to you.
$1,000  Perk - Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a
Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our
website’s Hall of Donor page.
Dioxin Free World Medal of Honor, Global Plastoil Member’s T-shirt, Dioxin Free World Campaign Cap, Global Plastoil Honor Membership Certificate
will be delivered to you.
$5,000 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of
change to help make a Dioxin free World.  Your name will be inscribed on our
website’s Hall of Donor page.
Global Plastoil Member’s T-shirt, Dioxin Free World Campaign Cap, Global Plastoil Honor Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Plaque of Honor will
be delivered to you.
$10,000 Perk -  Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a
Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our
website’s Hall of Donor page.
Global Plastoil Member’s T-shirt, Dioxin Free World Campaign Cap, Global Plastoil Honor Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Plaque of Honor will
be delivered to you.
Just arrive at Incheon International Airport, Korea, we invite you to 3 nights stay in prestigious hotel in Seoul including meals and domestic transportation, Guest of Honor at the
Dedication Day Ceremony of the world first Plastoil Plant and reception party.
$50,000 Perk - Your precious commitment initiates a tide of change to help make a
Dioxin free World. Your name will be inscribed on our
website’s Hall of Donor page.
Global Plastoil Member’s T-shirt, Dioxin Free World Campaign Cap, Global Plastoil Honor Membership Certificate, Dioxin Free World Plaque of Honor will
be delivered to you.
 Just arrive at Incheon International Airport, Korea, we invite you to  6 nights stay in  prestigious hotel in Seoul, Jeju Island and spiritual
Temple Stay at a thousand year old buddhist temple,  including meals and domestic transportation,  Guest of Honor at the Dedication Day Ceremony of the world first Plastoil Plant and reception party.








The Impact 

There are no tolerable emission levels
for Dioxins, which are one of the most toxic chemicals existing on earth, owing
to the resistance to degradation, accumulated in the environment through food
chain, causing severe disadvantages to the human health and natural ecology,
even with a minimal emission level.


Organic wastes other than waste plastics
also cause Dioxin emission when incinerated, but most of them could be composted to give
fertilizers for farming or decomposed in the land-fill, whereas waste plastics
could not be land-filled because they resist decomposition, which make waste
plastics to be the major source of Dioxin generation in the incinerators. Worldwide Plastoil
projects will convert waste plastics to oil, to prevent incineration of waste plastics, to minimize the Dioxin generation all around the world to save
the environment. 







There are no other practical measures to eliminate the millions of tons of waste plastics contained in the garbage patches in the Oceans. 
Plastoil Salvage Vessel equiped with Plastoil unit launched to the garbage patches in the Oceans,  would be able to convert the millions of tons of waste plastics to millions of barrels of oil, in situ, self sufficing not only  the fuel for the voyage but also to account for the cost to clean-up the coastlines of the contaminated islands.







Risks & Challenges

 

Plastics pyrolysis process is a highly
hazardous process and maximum safety precautions are required for the safe
operation of the Plastoil plants. PCR process, fail-safe nitrogen sealed, fully automated continuous,  SCADA control system is developed to ensure safety of the operators and the facility,
eliminating any chances of irreversible disaster.
Intensive drill and precautions are also
required for the operators to be ready for the confrontation of an unforeseeable
disasters. Crisis techniques are mastered by years of in situ experiences
of confronting series of life risking critical experiences as project
manager in fine chemical process plants and development projects. 
Plastoil plants adopting State-of-the-Art PCR process always guarantee maximum safety of the operators and the facility and minimize the contamination of the environment.















Other Ways You Can Help


 You can always help prevent generation of Dioxins by expelling usage of expendable containers to reduce plastics and film wastes in everyday life and save the environment.

story:
Short Summary

Hi, My name is Travis. 

For the last few years I have been doing a ton of research on how to become a beekeeper.

Sadly enough, most of the information I was able to find was how critical the bee population has become.  It is said that the bee population is losing their numbers by 1/3 every year world wide.

There are several theories as to the bee collapse.  What really matters is that there are people like you and I that won't wait for them to be gone before we try to help. 

What I do know is that my dad and I have maintained 5 hives from May 2014 till right now, October 12 2014.  I believe that I have found something that I can be great at, and will continue to learn. 

With your help, We will do everything in our power to keep them alive One Hive at a Time.

We have already put enough money in the survival of the bees, we could have enough honey to last a life time.  Instead, we have decided to use it to protect and serve the Honeybee population with an ongoing attempt to ensure the survival of our own, and plans to add more hives each and every year.


What We Need & What You Get

Beekeeping supplies all in itself isn't cheap.  It will cost approximately $300 a hive, just to get the bees and build home for them.  Not to mention the resources to keep these bees warm in our brutal Minnesota winters.  Some of you are unable to keep bees for various reasons.  This is your opportunity support the bee population and have faith in our beekeeping skills, without physically having them. 


The Impact

 Saving these bees is very important.  If these bees dissapear, we all will be in a world of hurt.
If we can save ONE hive every year, that will make a difference.  Help us out.


Risks & Challenges

Like any living thing, there will be many challenges along the way. I can only provide for these bees what I know, and what I can learn along the way.  Hive survival is never a guarantee.

I believe that the biggest challenge that we will face is the cold Minnesota winter, which we have already come up with a few ideas on how to take action.


Please take the time to check out my picture gallery, We started with 5 hives, and I have pictures of 5 working hives...Thanks to my dad and I, All 5 are still going strong.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word to everyone you know.  Support Local beekeepers.  Get a suit, equipment, and hive supplies and do it yourself.  The stings are worth it.

story:
This courageous American urgently needs $417  in order for his case to proceed in the courthouse on June 20th. Without this money, one of Michael's legal battles will be lost before it can even be heard. 

If there is to be any hope of winning the fight against the KXL, the battle has to be waged on all fronts, including in the courts. But legal costs are overwhelming, and Michael is tapped out. By donating to his legal expenses, you will be playing an active rôle in the fight against the Keystone XL pipeline.

Background: A lower court judge recently ruled that he had no jurisdiction over the case -- without hearing Bishop's arguments against TransCanada's interpretation of eminent domain and other critical issues like the fact the pipeline will move tar sands (bitumen)  not crude oil as landowners were told it would. Bishop, acting as his own lawyer, has launched an appeal (for which he has had to pay hundreds of dollars already). He didn't know he would also be required to pay for the transcript of the flawed ruling, but he is. That's were you come in. He can't afford this additioanl fee. Any funds you contribute will make you an active participant in Bishop's leagel defense. 
 
Every dollar counts. Please join this campaign and contribute to Michael Bishop's cause. He is fighting for all of us and the health of our planet.  
 
Michael Bishop is waging another lawsuit against the Army Corps of Engineers -- accusing the federal government of not giving Texas equal protection under the Clean Air and Water Act, among other things. If he wins either of these cases, construction of the southern end of the Keystone XL pipeline would be stopped by means of legal channels whether or not Obama approves the northern route.
 
In his own words here is how he is challenging the KLX southern route: 
 
"I have filed a class action suit against the Army Corps of Engineers in Federal Court (Eastern District of Texas/Lufkin) on behalf of landowners in Oklahoma and Texas and that includes a writ of mandamus to enforce the ACE to hold PUBLIC hearings and for the court to order the permit to TCK revoked.  I also have a suit filed in Travis County, Texas (Austin) against the Texas Railroad Commission, the permitting agency for pipelines in Texas.  It is also a writ of mandamus which will order the Commission to revoke the permit they issued to TransCanada.  There are other legal actions planned and pending.  I now have a total of three (3) legitimate lawsuits filed in local, state and federal courts."
 
 
* Note-in the video clip for this campaign  Bishop mentions he needs $761 . He has a lot going on and got that amount wrong in the clip. Any additional funds Bishop may get will go to the other case he is waging and one he is about to launch in light of the anomalies. 
 
 
Read Michael Bishop's story in his own words on Eco Watch:
Part 1 http://ecowatch.com/2013/one-mans-stand-keystone-xl/
 
Part 2 http://ecowatch.com/2013/transcanada-court-keystone-xl/
part 3 http://ecowatch.com/2013/fight-against-keystone-xl/
 
 
Additional Feature on Bishop in Earth Isand Journal 
http://www.earthisland.org/journal/index.php/elist/eListRead/us_marine_vet_fights_transcanada_over_keystone_xl/

story:
I want to help.

 I see the global issues that we are facing finding shelter, access to drinking water, people who have no way of feeding themselves, and so do you. The corporate world pulls the strings and we dance to a tune we don’t like. Working for the past five years as a volunteer and activist with Greenpeace I feel like I’ve been of use. Still, I want to step it up, I want to be able to propose solutions and BUILD solutions.

  For countless years I have been trying to imagine a self-sustainable home. This desire often surfaces in my mind and I feel a strong urge to build something that will protect me from fluctuating markets, oil peeks, pesticides, pollution, economic recessions, the 9-5 job that will allow me to just get by (you get the point). Then, one evening a friend and I stumble upon a documentary that we end up watching that talks about Earthships. Bingo! I feel like I’ve just won the lottery!

  

At that point I told myself I needed to get down to the Academy as soon as I could. And so it is. It’s set in stone, (or tires, whatever) I am happy to announce that I am going to be part of the earthship academy 2013 fall session!

 Now the fun begins!

 I have decided to make my way down to Taos, New Mexico by bike. In doing so I hope to underline that one can travel around the globe with a reduced carbon footprint as well as illustrate some of the amazing encounters one makes when using alternative forms of transportation.

Montreal to New Mexico Map 

Departure August 1st 2013 from Montreal

Arrival (approx.) September 12th 2013 in Taos, New Mexico

 

 The Breakdown

So! So! So! I want to finance my trip, tuition AND fundraise for an Earthship style community center in Malawi, Africa. 

  • 500$ to help me bike from Montreal to New Mexico
  • 2000$ for the six week course offered by the Earthship Academy
  • Every extra penny is donated to the Malawi Earthship project in Africa.

  

 

  

What are Earthships and why do I believe in them?

 Here are the six design principles of an Earthhip

 

  1. Building with natural and recycled materials
  2. Producing your own food
  3. On site sewage treatment
  4. Solar passive energy, ‘’heating’’ using thermal mass
  5. Produce your own electricity (solar/wind)
  6. Capture and re-use of rainwater

 

 At this point in my life I feel I need to promote solutions in a concrete way. This type of building seems to answer a lot of pressing questions and has major pieces of the puzzle we are trying to solve. It is possible to build a home that captures rainwater, produces your own food, that drastically reduces heating and cooling costs and, not to mention the use of society’s ‘’garbage’’ to make it all possible.

 I’m not the only one that wants this for myself. You can help me help you help others realize this common dream. I think it’s high time we BE the change…. Let’s make it happen.

 I want to help this concept evolve and my next step is to follow the academy course offered this fall.

 

                                Greenpeace bike tour

 

Why by bike?

It’s not the first time that I do this sort of thing. Last summer I organized a two-man 1500km bike tour through Québec to help raise awareness and fundraise for Greenpeace. I feel that while talking to people about environmental issues it’s important not only speak of but abide by the values you are hoping to share with those you encounter.

 

 So far I have….  

Had the chance to see Mike Reynolds, the founder of the earthship concept, give a three day conference in Toronto explaining the evolution of this amazing building and how it all began. I was particularly interested by the projects his crew leads internationally, sharing his knowledge and helping communities learn how to build this structure themselves.

 For more information check this out!

http://earthship.com

   I have also had the chance to meet with Francis Gendron, founder of l’Ère des Solutions, and help organize a very successful conference in Montreal where he illustrated the ins and outs of earthship structures in French.  He has graciously offered to help me with the funding of this campaign by offering up plans for his Solar Passive Greenhouse design as well as seats to any further conferences he will be giving through the upcoming months.

 Pour les ami(e)s qui veulent plus d’info

http://www.solutionera.com

I will be documenting my trip and keeping a blog that will allow people to follow my trip from start to finish. The blog will be kept up to date by a friend and fellow student of the academy as well as myself and will serve to follow not only my trip but also our experience at the academy. This is once again in the hopes of stimulating peoples curiosity about this type of building and helping in whatever way I can spread what Mike Reynolds likes to call the Virus.

How can you help?

Sharing this campaign is going to help me go a long way….literally! So just passing the word around and showing the campaign to people you think might be interested will definitely get me there!

 

Merci!

How can you help?

Merci!

story:
Our Goal

To create a design-based performance piece in response to the 2011 Prague Quadrennial that examines materials, and then organizes and redistribute (would be wasted) materials to the local arts community.

Our Story

The Center for Sustainable Practice in the Arts is a hybrid organization dedicated to gathering and redistributing information about sustainable practices in art making.  This project marks our first initiative to solve one of the major dilemmas of creating art on the ground:  Wasted Materials!  We will travel to Prague this summer to focus on the environmental impact of production at the 2011 Prague Quadrennial and will creatively repurpose the waste generated from this 10-day design conference of over seventy exhibiting countries.  


Organizing team members include Ian Garrett and Miranda Wright (co-founders of the Center for Sustainable Practice in the Arts), Sarah Peterson (Production Manager, Theater Artist, New York CSPA Associate), Moe Beitiks (artist, cultural volunteer, and writer for inhabitat, CBOT, and the CSPA), Misa Rygrova (leading researcher on this topic in the Czech Republic), and James McKernan (faculty at York University and Technical Director for the PQ's Scenofest).  


The PQ

The Prague Quadrennial of Performance Design and Space is a leading world artistic event – a presentation of contemporary work in a variety of performance design disciplines and genres including costume, stage, lighting, sound design, and theatre architecture for dance, opera, drama, site-specific, multi-media performances, and performance art. 


Founded in 1967, the Prague Quadrennial has presented work from more than 70 countries on 5 continents. The exhibition draws thousands of performance and theatre professionals, students, and spectators from all over the world. At the most recent Quadrennial in 2007, 35,000 visitors came to enjoy installations, photos, videos, and live performances of work ranging between theatre and visual arts, as well as more than 500 events, workshops, performances, presentations, lectures, and discussions. 


The Impact

This project will be a significant catalyst for the advancement of sustainability in theater and design.  It is an opportunity to develop a comprehensive case study on community engagement in creative resource management.  As a performance, it will examine the relationship of production communities from around the world to their use of materials practically and dramaturgically.  It will create new methods for distributing large amounts of previously used materials quickly, test the limits of a community's ability to absorb the material, and develop a mode of a working network of materials exchange.  


What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for $4,000 in additional funding to supplement travel for our team, and to provide resources and tools for distributing materials and documenting this project.  


We promise to give you what we get:  INFORMATION!  We'll be documenting this project, and will gladly share our findings with you.  Other perks include copies of the CSPA Quarterly, a publication dedicated to sustainable practices in all creative areas, CSPA membership, and special tokens from the PQ!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!  Share this project with your friends and colleagues.  

To support the greater effort of the CSPA, become a member by visiting www.sustainablepractice.org/join-the-cspa
story_txt:
Our Goal
To create a design-based performance piece in response to the 2011 Prague Quadrennial that examines materials, and then organizes and redistribute (would be wasted) materials to the local arts community.

Our Story
The Center for Sustainable Practice in the Arts is a hybrid organization dedicated to gathering and redistributing information about sustainable practices in art making.  This project marks our first initiative to solve one of the major dilemmas of creating art on the ground:  Wasted Materials!  We will travel to Prague this summer to focus on the environmental impact of production at the 2011 Prague Quadrennial and will creatively repurpose the waste generated from this 10-day design conference of over seventy exhibiting countries.  

Organizing team members include Ian Garrett and Miranda Wright (co-founders of the Center for Sustainable Practice in the Arts), Sarah Peterson (Production Manager, Theater Artist, New York CSPA Associate), Moe Beitiks (artist, cultural volunteer, and writer for inhabitat, CBOT, and the CSPA), Misa Rygrova (leading researcher on this topic in the Czech Republic), and James McKernan (faculty at York University and Technical Director for the PQ's Scenofest).  

The PQ
The Prague Quadrennial of Performance Design and Space is a leading world artistic event – a
presentation of contemporary work in a variety of performance design
disciplines and genres including costume, stage, lighting, sound design, and
theatre architecture for dance, opera, drama, site-specific, multi-media
performances, and performance art. 

Founded in 1967, the
Prague Quadrennial has presented work from more than 70 countries on 5
continents. The exhibition draws thousands of performance and theatre
professionals, students, and spectators from all over the world. At the most
recent Quadrennial in 2007, 35,000 visitors came to enjoy installations,
photos, videos, and live performances of work ranging between theatre and
visual arts, as well as more than 500 events, workshops, performances,
presentations, lectures, and discussions. 





The Impact
This project will be a significant catalyst for the advancement of sustainability in theater and design.  It is an opportunity to develop a comprehensive case study on community engagement in creative resource management.  As a performance, it will examine the relationship of production communities from around the world to their use of materials practically and dramaturgically.  It will create new methods for distributing large amounts of previously used materials quickly, test the limits of a community's ability to absorb the material, and develop a mode of a working network of materials exchange.  


What We Need & What You Get
We are looking for $4,000 in additional funding to supplement travel for our team, and to provide resources and tools for distributing materials and documenting this project.  

We promise to give you what we get:  INFORMATION!  We'll be documenting this project, and will gladly share our findings with you.  Other perks include copies of the CSPA Quarterly, a publication dedicated to sustainable practices in all creative areas, CSPA membership, and special tokens from the PQ!

Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word!  Share this project with your friends and colleagues.  
To support the greater effort of the CSPA, become a member by visiting www.sustainablepractice.org/join-the-cspa

story:
Short Summary

THE CHALLENGE: Raise $5000 for the an OCPS Green Tag website project

Reducing energy costs for schools is a focus for all school districts in these fiscally challenging times. The Orange County Public Schools Solar Energy Program helps schools reduce costs by generating energy at nine OCPS schools  and  in many cases, transferring excess energy back to the grid. The OCPS Solar Program, which was started back in 1999, has by the end of June 2014, generated an estimated 2084 MWhrs of energy. This has resulted in savings, at current Florida energy prices, worth $208,400 conserving over 1400 tons of Carbon.

The Orange County Public Schools Solar program has brought together school administrators, code officials, teachers, students, parents, solar industry professionals, researchers, emergency management and utility personnel to work toward a common goal. It has created a community of solar advocates throughout Orange County and successfully engaged our students in the amazing power of renewable energy. 


The money allotted for the maintenance of OCPS campuses is prioritized based on keeping the schools running. The loss of use of our OCPS solar panels does not affect the day to day running  of the schools and has therefore received a very low priority. With virtually no maintenance or priority, the efficiency of these systems can be reduced and eventually lead to malfunctioning. The OCPS Energy Management team estimates that OCPS will need $6500 / year to keep our solar systems maintained. Just as you would get your oil changed and car checked each year, or you would get a physical from your doctor, these solar systems need to be cleaned, inspected, and repaired as well. 

In order to keep these donated solar systems efficient and in working order, OCPS would like to create a website that will allow the purchase of Renewable Energy Certificates created from the generation of pollution free energy. These Certificates are also called ‘Green Tags’ and will be sold to generate funds for maintaining the Solar Energy System that Orange County Public Schools operates.

The cost of the Green Tag Website is estimated to be $5000.

THE GREEN TAG WEB SITE

In America today, most of the electricity generated is through the burning coal and fossil fuels, which directly contributes to the production of pollution, greenhouse gases, and many believe:  climate change. We understand that the reduction of this pollution will aid in keeping our local and global environment healthy. Through the production of electricity using renewable sources, such as the light of the sun, our goal of reducing pollution becomes a reality. Currently, OCPS utilized nine systems using  Photovoltaics (PV) and solar thermal panels, which produce pollution free electricity and heat.  

GREEN TAGS are called by many names. They are also known as:

•  Green Certificates  

•  Green Credits

•  Renewable Energy Credits (RECs)

Green Tags represent an individual’s support for clean, alternative energy. The Green Tag website which we will develop after the successful Iniegogo campaign will be used to allow members of the public access to purchasing these Green Tags. The Green Tags website will allow the public the ability, in a small or large way, to show support of the production of clean electricity generated on the campuses of our nine OCPS schools. 

Funds Raised

The goal of this project is to raise $5000.  If this Indiegogo Campaign receives more than the required $5000 for the creation of the Green Tags website, the excess amount will go directly into our Green Tags Program. 

The Impact

A successful launch of the Green Tags program will:


Aid in the establishment of the OCPS Green Tags Program which will create funding for maintenance and education: 

  • Half of the money will go specifically toward the maintenance of the current solar installations and all future installations. This includes paying for repair and preventative maintenance in the following ways:

            1.  Clean Solar Panels
            2.  Check the Performance of Solar System 
            3.  Inspect for Operational Failures and Structural Damage
            4.  Inspect for Insect, bird and animal damage
            5.  Replace any damaged equipment

  • Half of the money raised will go directly back to the nine schools who currently have solar installations on their campuses. This money will that goes to the schools will be used for STEM and renewable energy education of the staff and students at the principal’s discretion. If there are additional solar schools added during the green tags program, the money will go toward these schools as well.

Provide a unique opportunity for over 11,000 students every year to learn about solar energy and ways that it helps their community and save energy.

Help a public school system save on energy expenses and maintain equipment provided to the tax payers that is worth over ($500,000) five hundred thousand dollars.

story:
Friends of the Atchafalaya is encouraging all friends to help raise money to support the Atchafalaya Swamp Base. Here’s the deal. The Friends of the Atchafalaya want to help the Evangeline Area Council Boy Scouts by buying at least one of the Atchafalaya Kayaks, the “Atchafalayak,” that the Scouts are using for their Swamp Base. Each kayak costs about $1,200. Friends of the Atchafalaya is offering to contribute $500 toward the cost of one kayak and you can help us raise the rest. We hope to reach our goal by February 14, 2015, before the Swamp Base opens for 2015 trekkers.

Whether we reach the goal of the full purchase price of an Atchafalayak, we will donate the entire amount raised to the Evangeline Area Council to be used to support the Swamp Base. If we raise more money than the cost of a kayak we will give any additional funds raised to the Swamp Base. Lets see what we can do together.

If you want more information about the Swamp Base project go to bsaswampbase.org. Both Friends of the Atchafalaya and Evangeline Council are 501c3 organizations so your contribution will be tax deductible. We will send you the needed tax numbers with our thank you letter for your gift.

The donor making the largest single donation will be given a personally autographed copy of Bryan Piazza’s book “The Atchafalaya Basin: History and Ecology of an American Wetland”.

Friends of the Atchafalaya is an affiliate of the Louisiana Wildlife Federation and appreciates the support of the Federation in launching this campaign.

story:
Short Summary

Who is David Clark?

I have over the years been involved in electrical and mechanical environments and held positions from forklift driver to General Manager which have been the greatest training ground for diversification.

And I have identified many areas that we can help the planet and save ourselves some money.

All funding will go to the ZCP Zero Carbon Power project only, which is completing the development of inline water generators for domestic use. Locally and third world countries.

Each day people install solar on their roofs to help reduce the electricity bill. Solar only works in the sunlight. Every day you turn on a tap, flush the toilet, have a shower and hose the garden, our system goes inline with you water mains, and on your pool filter, similar to a mini hydro system, yet completely different. It will generate energy that can be connected to your solar inverter and place electricity back on the grid day and night. Systems will be small and dependent on your water usage, but in the majority of cases you use more electricity in the dark, after work etc, than during the day. It is envisaged that an average home will generate 1-5kw per day, not a great amount but at rising electricity costs, long term anything is a bonus, business will generate greater returns.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The funding raised will be directly used in the further research and development of the product, the building of proto-types through to the next stage of either development or marketing.

We are seeking $250,000.00 to get the project to the next stage, I have already invested personally over $50,000 so now it is getting closer to proto-type because I have already proven a lot of ways it will not work. This stage is bringing in the "experts" to refine findings, testing and bring the product to the next stage.

Each contribution will bring the project closer to the finish line as that means that the units will be able to have incremental growth and another part tested, manufactured, approved etc, it will keep the momentum going.

Support or perks will be at the end of the fund raising period but I believe that any support should be rewarded so, "We will if full amount raised" move all rewards (up to $1,000 bracket), double or up to the next level.

At certain levels you will start to receive paper weights of the generators.

The Impact

Optimist or pessimist:

If we develop this product so the average person can afford and install in the home, we have helped save the planet, reduce pollution, your electricity bill and the terrible waste of natural resources, if I do not, who will and every time your have water flow through your home, which one will you be, one who tried by supporting or the other.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.
