story:
Story

The project started in 2006 when David Solberg, an expert in sustainable energy, started an international project and concluded that environmental issues such as climate change, water scarcity, and air pollution were the result of the inefficient use of non-renewable resources and excessive dependency on fossil fuels. Due to this, Solberg came up with an innovative methodology that uses the concept of Exergy. 



But what is Exergy? Exergy is not only the maximum potential of the energy. It is also the optimal use of water and other resources with minimal emissions and contaminants.

so, what did we do?

We created the project called Galileo’s Eye. We made this analogy because  Galileo was the one who invented the telescope to allow us to see the world with the right lenses. We used the right lenses to show how Exergy can improve our resource potential and therefore create a more sustainable world.

The project has been broken-down in four phases.

In phase 1, we applied the methodology in Twin Cities Minnesota obtaining savings of 73% and 39% in water fuel.


Now we need to share it for the benefit of our society!

How?

In phases 2 and 3, we will extend the methodology to the entire state of Minnesota and a waste treatment in Medellin, Colombia. With the outputs we obtained from them, we will be able to use the data in the development of the consumer software.


Why do we need your support?

We are grateful that we have the continued support of the scientific community and organisations who believe in the project; however, the development of the software is quite costly; your support will help our ideas come to life.

For the development of the app we need to dedicate a huge amount of resources to:

- Subcontract researchers to collect and analyze data

- Implement the use of QR in products, building, facilities in the two pilot tests in Minnesota and Medellin

- Hire professionals to develop the app

- Test the app all around the world

Through the Indiegogo campaign, our goal is to achieve a total of $500.000 to collect data, carry out field work, extend the methodology to a large community, and develop the first version of the consumer app.

Besides having access to the app you will be able to take advantage of a range of exciting perks related to our technology!  

If we do not achieve our funding goal, we will continue working on the project with the available funds, reconsider the scope of work, and pick the most suitable actions to develop our ideas. 


How does the consumer app work?

The software is simple-to-use tool accessible via computers and smart devices that compares the performance of your assets (house, appliances, devices, etc).

You will only:

-  Scan: accessible through QR codes that can be found on your assets and products

-  Analyze: sustainable performance ratings including utility bills

-  Compare: the optimal sustainable performance of your assets and advice on how to reduce your bills.

For example, you could compare the lifetime utility bills of two different houses when buying or renting a property based on their optimal sustainable performance or compare the fuel consumption during lifetime of two different cars (electric vs.  Petrol/diesel).

It means that you will be able to make decisions based on real facts, saving time, money and at the same time being an active part in the improvement of global environmental quality.


Features

-  Combines energy and environmental parameters

-  Import tool for existing 2D/3D computerized models

-  Weather/climate data scenarios

-  Monitoring and reporting software

-  Records current and history data

-  Forecasting tool

-  Intelligent notification system

-  Comparative questionnaires

- Automated email notifications
Team

We are Dave and Fernando from Solberg Engineering LLC and Exergy Ltd. 

According to the reputed scientist Stephen Hawking "We should colonise other planets to protect the human race". Dr. Hawking, as many others, thinks that human aggression could bring nuclear war or other self-destructive events.

We are already experiencing global warming and its consequences can lead to an uncertain future for the next generations. We feel that we shouldn't give up and work towards providing a better planet for them. This is the only habitable planet in the solar system and we'd better take care of it! We hope that we can contribute to create a more sustainable world. That's why we are trying to convert Galileo's Eye into a tool that the society can use to revert the current trend.

We wish to make this tool available for citizens. Now you have the power to change the present and make a better future! 

Help us spread the word to the world!

Many great ideas are not moving forward because we are simply not well informed. Tell your family, friends, co-workers, neighbours, those who you love and those who you don't. This will be a huge change for our world and together we can make it a reality!


More info: http://galileoseyeproject.com/

story:
Summary

Studies have shown that 67% of street litter is food industry disposables, much of which is single-use plastic. Our beaches and oceans are increasingly becoming home to everlasting 'disposable' plastics. At the very least they ruin the beauty of our surroundings, more tragically, they pollute our environment with toxic chemicals and end in death for our land and sea wildlife.

Our goal is to establish a membership base whose combined voice will convey their desire for environmentally responsible restaurants. We will use that collective voice to encourage restaurants to work with us toward eliminating single-use plastics and improving their overall sustainability. 

We will inspire action by providing educational opportunities and community events for our restaurants and supporters to collaborate and create solutions toward our mission.

Sound good? Become a member today!

WHO WE SERVE

PATRONS

Seacoast residents are politically, socially, and environmentally progressive — and they want to support like-minded, environmentally conscious businesses. Yet they face a dilemma when they want to eat out or order in. The Seacoast has many local restaurants with amazing food and service, but some still rely on unsustainable practices and environmentally detrimental single-use plastics. We believe the restaurant-going public should not have to choose between enjoying a great meal or boycotting a restaurant for the betterment of the environment.

THE RESTAURANTS

The Seacoast food and beverage industry is a vibrant, growing scene — many of these restaurants, breweries, and cafes want to adopt more environmentally conscious practices, yet don’t possess the knowledge or resources to reach their sustainability goals. We are creating programs to educate these restaurants and provide resources to help them convert away from single-use plastics, helping them protect the places their patrons and community love.

THE EARTH

In the end, our biggest beneficiary is our planet. The environment, wildlife, and our fellow humans will all enjoy a better future when we work together toward leaving the planet in better shape for future generations.

Challenges

Just like everywhere else in the world we have a single-use plastic problem. Plastic bags, cups, straws, utensils, and to-go containers. There are processes that we're all stuck in, the "on the go" culture where convenience is the main concern. This way of life is creating a huge plastic pollution problem around the world. It's littering our streets, the oceans, and working its way into the food chain.

The Seacoast community is ready for a challenge, ready to lead the way and set an example of how a community of concerned citizens and committed restaurants can work together to inspire positive change.

Facts & Stats

  • The United States uses more than 500,000,000 plastic straws per day... PER DAY!
  • Sustainable Seacoast has already helped keep thousands of straws out of use.
  • less than 25% of plastic gets recycled, food service plastic is often not recyclable.
  • Sustainable Seacoast is working with restaurants to increase use of reusables.
  • Americans use 25 Billion disposable styrofoam coffee cups every day.
  • Sustainable Seacoast member restaurants do not use styrofoam cups.
  • The average American throws away 10 plastic bags per week.
  • Sustainable Seacoast member restaurants do not offer plastic bags.
  • Studies show consumers are more likely to support sustainably minded brands.
  • Sustainable Seacoast member restaurants are committed to continued sustainability.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $17,500 with this campaign and 1000 members by the end of this year!

Your contribution will go toward:

  • Designing programs and consulting for restaurants to improve sustainability practices
  • Building education opportunities for consumers on single-use plastics and sustainability topics
  • Hosting networking events for our restaurants to collaborate on sustainability initiatives
  • Hosting pop-up events for our patron members at member restaurants
  • Public outreach opportunities to grow awareness of our mission and the single-use plastic problem
  • Supporting our administrative needs

Membership benefits:

  • Discounts at participating member restaurants
  • Invitations to pop-up events at rotating member restaurants
  • Invitations to members-only educational events
  • Free/reduced costs to film screenings
  • Access to a directory of member restaurants
  • Access to networking opportunities with restaurants and other members
  • All the warm fuzzies of knowing you're making the world a better place!

The Impact

Local is at the heart of everything we do. Seacoast residents like yourself have a chance to be a catalyst to a bigger movement. We know that our progressive community can lead the way towards cleaner coastlines and a less polluted planet. By joining forces with local businesses, organizations, and caring community members, we can reduce our environmental impact and influence lasting change in the restaurant industry and beyond.

So get involved. Support Sustainable Seacoast restaurants and other environmentally friendly businesses. Remain sustainably aware. Volunteer at one of our events. The environment needs our help, and we don’t have to sacrifice the things we love to do that. Our community has the opportunity to stand as one and definitively support a healthier environment. Let’s do this together.

Sustainable Seacoast is already seeing incredible success. Currently, we have signed on 17 member restaurants that have committed to reducing their impact on the environment, with your help we will continue to convert more restaurants! Our first steps have resulted in new sustainability commitments like eliminating plastic bags and adopting “straw on demand’ programs that will keep thousands of straws out of landfills and our nearby ocean. With your help, we will continue to connect with Seacoast restaurants and work with them on next step opportunities in their sustainability journey.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Not interested in perks? You can donate by clicking the 'BACK IT'

Thank you, we are so appreciative of your donation and membership!

There are many other ways you can help! Spread the word by sharing our campaign using the Indiegogo share tools and tell your friends how excited you are about our mission and how passionate you are about protecting the places you love.

Volunteer when you can, and spread the word!!

story:
JOIN US TO UNCOVER THE SECRETS OF THE POLAR NIGHT

This unique Arctic science project will involve a multi-phase expedition, culminating in a world-first winter journey to the Geographic North Pole. The preceding months will allow the team to collect an array of scientific data never before possible.

Vast gaps exist in scientists' knowledge of the melting sea ice across the vast Arctic Ocean. Whilst more is learned each year about the changing climate in the sunny season - spring and summer - the months of winter darkness are still a forbidding enigma. 

The Dark Ice Project

First conceived over five years ago and having gone through a series of preparatory testing phases, the Arctic Ocean expedition named descriptively as the Dark Ice Project is one of a kind. Its concept is the work of polar expedition leader Alex Hibbert and brings back into the fray trusted past teammates. George Bullard was Alex's partner on the record-breaking 1374-mile Long Haul expedition and James Wheeldon has worked with Alex in the Greenlandic High Arctic and in Iceland's notorious winter months.

This trio have researched, reworked and optimised their audacious plan to combine genuine, novel and useful environmental science with one of the most ambitious exploratory polar expeditions of times past or present.

The Phases of the Expedition

  1. BOAT. Launching from some of the northernmost shores of land anywhere on Earth (exact location is currently under wraps), the team will travel north in a modified science craft through the last weeks prior to the onslaught of the winter freeze-up.
  2. DRIFT. Using special equipment, they will set up a floating, drifting headquarters on the dynamic sea ice of the Arctic Ocean. This phase will allow for many weeks of the most ambitious scientific work. All will occur in the darkness of polar winter.
  3. SKI. Once in position and taking into account weather, drift and dozens of other factors, the Dark Ice team then take to skis and complete the final few hundred miles across pressure ridges and open water to the North Pole. Theirs will be the first to reach the North Pole in true winter conditions and without resupplies. They will have lightweight science instruments with them in order to continue their work and widen the sphere of discovery.

Why we need you!

As with any major journey, we will be partnering with a series of corporate allies, scientific grants and academic funding bodies. This complex network will ensure that every cog in the machine works on schedule and meets with success.

Of course, funding is tight. It always is, and in the world of polar expeditions, the last decade has made this even harder. As well as highly-specialised science goals with top universities and international environmental institutions, the team are passionate about 'open science' - that is, more basic yet still important data of a variety of types we can publish free, to the public.

This is where you come in. Woven into our journey will be our open science work and we need your assistance to make this as big, and as valuable to all, as possible.

The more we raise, the more we can do. Simple. £10,000 is a bare minimum and we implore you to help us smash through that initial target.

Why are we qualified? Why us?

Despite all being under the age of 32, the team have between them nearly a thousand days of serious, independent Arctic experience. They also hold a major polar world-record (the longest unsupported Arctic journey in history). A shared focus is for innovation - not copying previous ventures but instead driving their 'craft' forwards.

The team also bring a formidable scientific background to the table. There is no point doing science if it isn't done properly. The quality of data matters. Two science degrees from Oxford University and one from Edinburgh University will ensure that the surveying will be thorough and the data relevant.

What science are we contributing to and why?

The answer here is the most exciting part of our project. The sky is the limit and the better we're funded, the greater our depth and breadth.

Aside from our super-specialist collaborations with universities and global climate researchers, we hope to include the following open science data:

- Ocean salinity

- Temperature variations with depth and ice cover

- Ice thickness and stage of development through early and mid-winter

- Microbiology in sea water and sea ice

- True weather measurements to aid remote sensing calibration in winter

This data will be raw, whilst digestible, and released for free, global use by schools, citizens or higher educational organisations. Open Science.

*We can add to this with funding that exceeds our base target - please help us do more.*

Why? The Impact? This is clear: Climate Change is still one of the least understood existential threats to our planet, civilisation and the nature we live amongst. Winter processes are even more poorly researched due to the dangers of operating in the dark. This project can contribute to reversing these facts.

Risks and challenges

Any independent and highly-committed polar expedition involves risks. Ice conditions, weather and injuries can present challenges, but with a combination of experience and planning, these can be avoided or overcome.

Unforeseen events may foreshorten or delay one area of study, but allow others to continue.

---------

Thank you so much from the team for reading all the way through. We really hope that you can contribute to the project and help us find out more about the High Arctic in winter. More importantly, to share what we discover with as many as possible.

Aside from directly contributing, you can also do a great deal of good by spreading the word via social media or word of mouth.

That's all from us now, but stay tuned for updates!
story_txt:
JOIN US TO UNCOVER THE SECRETS OF THE POLAR NIGHT
This unique Arctic science project will involve a multi-phase expedition, culminating in a world-first winter journey to the Geographic North Pole. The preceding months will allow the team to collect an array of scientific data never before possible.
Vast gaps exist in scientists' knowledge of the melting sea ice across the vast Arctic Ocean. Whilst more is learned each year about the changing climate in the sunny season - spring and summer - the months of winter darkness are still a forbidding enigma. 

The Dark Ice Project
First conceived over five years ago and having gone through a series of preparatory testing phases, the Arctic Ocean expedition named descriptively as the Dark Ice Project is one of a kind. Its concept is the work of polar expedition leader Alex Hibbert and brings back into the fray trusted past teammates. George Bullard was Alex's partner on the record-breaking 1374-mile Long Haul expedition and James Wheeldon has worked with Alex in the Greenlandic High Arctic and in Iceland's notorious winter months.
This trio have researched, reworked and optimised their audacious plan to combine genuine, novel and useful environmental science with one of the most ambitious exploratory polar expeditions of times past or present.
The Phases of the Expedition

BOAT. Launching from some of the northernmost shores of land anywhere on Earth (exact location is currently under wraps), the team will travel north in a modified science craft through the last weeks prior to the onslaught of the winter freeze-up.
DRIFT. Using special equipment, they will set up a floating, drifting headquarters on the dynamic sea ice of the Arctic Ocean. This phase will allow for many weeks of the most ambitious scientific work. All will occur in the darkness of polar winter.
SKI. Once in position and taking into account weather, drift and dozens of other factors, the Dark Ice team then take to skis and complete the final few hundred miles across pressure ridges and open water to the North Pole. Theirs will be the first to reach the North Pole in true winter conditions and without resupplies. They will have lightweight science instruments with them in order to continue their work and widen the sphere of discovery.


Why we need you!
As with any major journey, we will be partnering with a series of corporate allies, scientific grants and academic funding bodies. This complex network will ensure that every cog in the machine works on schedule and meets with success.
Of course, funding is tight. It always is, and in the world of polar expeditions, the last decade has made this even harder. As well as highly-specialised science goals with top universities and international environmental institutions, the team are passionate about 'open science' - that is, more basic yet still important data of a variety of types we can publish free, to the public.
This is where you come in. Woven into our journey will be our open science work and we need your assistance to make this as big, and as valuable to all, as possible.
The more we raise, the more we can do. Simple. £10,000 is a bare minimum and we implore you to help us smash through that initial target.
Why are we qualified? Why us?
Despite all being under the age of 32, the team have between them nearly a thousand days of serious, independent Arctic experience. They also hold a major polar world-record (the longest unsupported Arctic journey in history). A shared focus is for innovation - not copying previous ventures but instead driving their 'craft' forwards.
The team also bring a formidable scientific background to the table. There is no point doing science if it isn't done properly. The quality of data matters. Two science degrees from Oxford University and one from Edinburgh University will ensure that the surveying will be thorough and the data relevant.
What science are we contributing to and why?
The answer here is the most exciting part of our project. The sky is the limit and the better we're funded, the greater our depth and breadth.

Aside from our super-specialist collaborations with universities and global climate researchers, we hope to include the following open science data:
- Ocean salinity
- Temperature variations with depth and ice cover
- Ice thickness and stage of development through early and mid-winter
- Microbiology in sea water and sea ice
- True weather measurements to aid remote sensing calibration in winter
This data will be raw, whilst digestible, and released for free, global use by schools, citizens or higher educational organisations. Open Science.
*We can add to this with funding that exceeds our base target - please help us do more.*
Why? The Impact? This is clear: Climate Change is still one of the least understood existential threats to our planet, civilisation and the nature we live amongst. Winter processes are even more poorly researched due to the dangers of operating in the dark. This project can contribute to reversing these facts.


Risks and challenges
Any independent and highly-committed polar expedition involves risks. Ice conditions, weather and injuries can present challenges, but with a combination of experience and planning, these can be avoided or overcome.
Unforeseen events may foreshorten or delay one area of study, but allow others to continue.

---------
Thank you so much from the team for reading all the way through. We really hope that you can contribute to the project and help us find out more about the High Arctic in winter. More importantly, to share what we discover with as many as possible.
Aside from directly contributing, you can also do a great deal of good by spreading the word via social media or word of mouth.
That's all from us now, but stay tuned for updates!

story:
We are calling on all energy companies, investors and individuals to agree to a global target of meeting at least 50% of electricity demand from renewable sources by 2050.


The 50/50 Campaign is mobilizing people power by rallying around 'Smart Energy Policies'. Together we can use people power to put these policies into practice and build a more balanced energy system regardless of place or politics.


50/50 is a joint initiative dreamed up by BlueWorks Global, a social enterprise striving to deliver the highest positive impact for communities around the globe and Nuovi, pioneers in digital development, marketing and sustainability strategy. Once we've met our fund-raising target, we'll put five key actions into motion that will help to launch 50/50 into the global spotlight.

Together we can use people power to ignite a global renewables revolution!

Why 50/50?

50/50 strikes a perfect balance between ambitious and realistic energy targets. Right now, the debate over our global energy future is divisive, with oil, gas and nuclear companies pitted against renewables. We believe the way forward is to adopt a balanced approach so that all energy companies can get on board to deliver a truly sustainable global energy system where everyone wins.

At the same time, it may be possible to meet more than 50% of global electricity demand from renewable sources by 2050. According to the IPCC up to 77% of the world's energy could come from renewables by 2050, so long as we adopt smarter policies. These policies have been defined by the World Resources Institute (WRI) as:

  • Comprehensive
  • Based on clearly defined objectives
  • Encouraging of private investment
  • Cost-effective
  • Supportive of innovation
  • Transparent, accountable and participatory

While the WRI drafted these policy recommendations for developing world governments, we at the 50/50 Campaign believe they ought to apply to all players in the global energy system regardless of place or politics, as well as to governments in both the 'developed' and 'developing' world. We don't need to wait for governments to act, we can deliver a global energy transformation RIGHT NOW.

How will a 50/50 target be achieved?

The 50/50 Campaign website will have three moving parts: a Smart Energy Policies Petition, a Power Map and a Power Blog. We'll also organize a conference AND with your help we'll invest 10% of all funds raised in a UK-based community renewable energy scheme. Together these 5 actions are at the Campaign's core.

1. Smart Energy Policies Petition: 

The most important part of the website will be the online petition. This is our call to action. Our aim is to collect as many online signatories as possible in support of the 50/50 target and Smart Energy Policies. Those who sign the petition will be making a pledge to put the Smart Energy Policies into practice in how they invest in, produce and consume energy. We don't need to wait for governments to act to build a sustainable future, we can do it with people power!

2. Power Map:

Renewable energy SMEs will be rewarded for signing the Smart Energy Policies Petition and linking back to the 50/50 Campaign website from their websites, by receiving a unique place on our Power Map. The Power Map will have a dedicated space on the 50/50 Campaign website, pinpointing and displaying contact information for renewable energy SMEs across the globe who have pledged to put Smart Energy Policies into practice. The purpose of the Power Map will be to show our support for fledgling companies in the renewable energy market by providing them with some free, top notch digital advertising.

3. Power Blog:

Power Blog will also have a special place on the 50/50 Campaign website - a place to form the knowledge hub, a one-stop-shop for expertise by some of the world's leading energy investment and sector experts. Power Blog will feature a wide range of original multimedia content and will include opinion articles on renewable energy and investment trends drawing attention to the 50/50 Campaign and providing some thought leadership. Nuovi have the skills and talent to deliver a specialist blog that can make some serious headway in getting the Campaign message out to major market players.

4. Annual Conference:

We're currently working on organizing a half-day conference for early February 2015 called 'Impact Investing and Renewable Energy: Bridging the Gap.' The Conference will feature expert panelists in impact investing and renewable energy from around the UK, US and globe. We're already busy securing support from our affiliates at University Business Schools and are looking forward to an event that can act as a launching pad for the 50/50 Campaign.

5. Community Energy Project:

We at BlueWorks Global are BIG on community renewables and local empowerment. To demonstrate how people power can lead to a global renewable energy transformation, we're going to put our money where our mouth is by investing 10% of total funds raised for the 50/50 Campaign into a community renewable energy project based in the UK. The community project chosen will be invited to table at our annual conference and to network with investors - which will hopefully help them with raising enough cash to meet their own fund-raising target. We're open to suggestions for a project, so please get in touch with the Campaign organizers if you have any suggestions. 

DOWNLOAD THE FULL SPONSORSHIP BROCHURE HERE: https://app.box.com/s/7o04svqjq2h4kl1jv6k8

What We Need & What You Get

  • We're asking for $50,000 to help support the web design, hosting, maintenance, campaign management, digital marketing and conference organising functions. 

  • Perks: for the first 50 donations of $50 or more, we'll send you a T-shirt and badge with our logo. All put together by the talented team at Nouvi.

  • If we don't reach our goal, we're still going to move forward with the Campaign it will just take a lot longer (this would be a bad thing, we need to mobilize global renewable energy action NOW).

The Impact

By donating to the 50/50 Campaign, you will be helping to accelerate a global renewable energy transformation. While renewable energy efficiency is improving and costs are coming down, we capture only a very small percentage of the global energy market. We need your help to grow our sector and our global influence.

Wider benefits of contributing support include, but aren't limited to:

  • Helping renewable energy SMEs to grow their exposure and access to potential clients and customers around the globe.

  • Kudos for having helped to kick start a Campaign with a long-term horizon, possibly running to 2050 (!)
  • Helping to get a community renewable energy project off the ground that will deliver major economic, social and environmental benefits.
  • Helping BlueWorks Global and Nuovi - both Edinburgh based SMEs - to grow their influence and raise their profiles.
  • By supporting the Campaign you will also be helping to support the work we do in trying to deliver services that can help to build, thriving and resilient communities of scale that are energy and IT equipped and prepared to weather the future global climate storm.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have any cash to contribute to the Campaign you can still help. Get in touch with us if you work for a company that you think might want to sponsor us or our upcoming Conference. We'd be delighted to hear from you!

story:
The above video portrays the production of our first sidewalk storybook.

THIS PROJECT: The second sidewalk storybook - Fukushima Response: Chieko’s Story will be produced by a group of local artists and activists on Saturday and Sunday, October 27-28, 2012. We will create the second production of a new art form in color chalk on the sidewalk at Penry Park in Petaluma, California. This 100-foot storybook will contain 12 panels of text and images that are each 8 feet in length. The tale is based on the true story of Chieko Shiina, who was displaced by the nuclear power plant disaster in Japan on March 11, 2011. (See story below.)

We will also create a  DOCUMENTARY VIDEO which will include the production of the 100 foot long storybook. The video will depict artists and volunteers creating the 12 chapter storybook and will include interviews with participating artists, anti-nuclear activists and passersby. This educational, community-building project will help to broaden international support and serve as a cautionary tale about the very real dangers of nuclear power.

Ten percent of the funds we raise for this project will be donated to Fukushima Response. Please check out the website below. http://fukushimaresponse.org

 

“Fukushima Response: Chieko’s Story”

This original story was adapted from public speeches by Chieko Shiina who was displaced by the destruction of the nuclear power plant in Fukushima, Japan on March 11, 2011.

By Tim Nonn, Beth Meredith and Eric Storm 

Chapter One

Story: Explosion and evacuation at Fukushima.

Text: Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster: March 11, 2011. As radiation spread, 200,000 residents were evacuated around the nuclear power plants operated by Tokyo Electric Power Company (TEPCO).

Images: (1) nuclear power plant explodes; (2) residents flee in terror.

Chapter Two

Story: Chieko Shiina, a woman who lives near Fukushima, is angry and sad about losing her business and way of life. 

Text: After 3/11 my life was turned upside down. I was shocked to realize I couldn’t grow vegetables without contamination and my grandchildren could longer visit me. Burning contaminated wood was like having a tiny nuclear power plant in my home. (40 words))

Images: (1) Chieko stares sadly at a photograph of her children and grandchildren; (2) she burns wood in a stone oven.

Chapter Three

Story: Chieko faces the hard reality of her life, which had been drastically changed by the disaster. She must decide where to live.

Text: For thirteen years I worked hard to create my home and farm, but now I had to leave it. I was sad and angry. Where should I live? I had the chance to move to an area with less radiation. 

Image: Chieko sits in a garden in deep thought. Above her head are two bubbles. One shows a nice way of life far away from Fukushima. The other shows her daughter and two grandchildren in the devastated city of Fukushima. 

Chapter Four

Story: Chieko decides to move closer to Fukushima to be with her daughter and two grandchildren. 

Text: But I worried about my youngest daughter and two grandchildren in Fukushima. Unlike me, they weren’t able to evacuate even though their town was more contaminated than mine. I couldn’t bear to leave them, so I moved to Fukushima.

Images: (1) Chieko reunited with her daughter and grandchildren in Fukushima; (2) destroyed nuclear power plant in the background. 

Chapter Five

Story: Chieko grapples with the dilemma of living in Fukushima.

Text: In Fukushima we can’t do simple things like breathing deeply outside or drying laundry in the sun. We live in uncertainty. Who caused 3/11? Who’s responsible for what happened after 3/11? I wanted to see things for myself and figure out what we should do.

Image: Chieko walking through the town and countryside looking at ruined rice fields, forests, sick children, lost pets and other scenes of devastation. 

Chapter Six

Story: Chieko witnesses first-hand the danger and hardships faced by residents every day in Fukushima. She becomes an anti-nuclear power activist.

Text: After moving to Fukushima, I devoted myself to stopping nuclear power in Japan. I founded a group called Fukushima Women against Nuclear Power.

Image: A group of women in a building with a sign that reads, Fukushima Women against Nuclear Power.

Chapter Seven

Story: Chieko’s new organization starts a grocery store.

Text: We began noticing strange looking plants and deformed butterflies. The school’s pet rabbit had a baby born without ears. I worried our food was contaminated, so we opened a small grocery store selling vegetables from non-contaminated areas.

Images: (1) Deformed plants, butterfly and rabbit; (2) grocery store with healthy vegetables and happy customers.

Chapter Eight

Story: The children in Fukushima are suffering more than the adults. 

Text: Mothers are very worried about their children. They get nose bleeds, coughs, eye problems, and colds that don’t end. The impact of contamination is five times worse for children than for adults. Our group helps children relocate, but some can’t leave due to family complications and financial issues.

Images: (1) Children being evacuated; (2) children staying behind.

Chapter Nine

Story: Government and nuclear industry are covering up the dangers of radiation.

Text: The government opened clinics to help people worried about their health and radiation. But these patients are silenced when they go to the doctor’s office. They are told, “It’s not the radiation. The problem is you’re too stressed out.” (39 words)

Image: Government clinic with a sign that says high radiation levels are safe.

Chapter Ten

Story: Construction begins on a new community clinic.

Text: We built our own clinic because we don’t trust the government doctors. We need this clinic to save the lives of our children. We can’t rely on the government, and the media is not telling the truth. We have to make our own future.

Image: A new clinic under construction - a sign reads, “We want our children to live and be healthy!”

Chapter Eleven

Story: Chieko travels to the United States to build support for the people of Fukushima.

Text: We struggle, but we have to go on. As a woman, I believe we must continue to fight because our children’s lives are in danger. We women must fight for them and help to unite everyone.

Images: (1) Chieko speaking at a rally in California; (2) the crowd applauding and people holding signs calling for an end to nuclear power, “We love (heart) Fukushima,” etc.

Chapter Twelve

Story: Chieko remembers her former happy life in Fukushima before 3/11.

Text: I remember waking up every day to the sound of birds and looking forward to a good day. As an organic farmer, I felt one with nature. In the summertime, I would catch fireflies with my grandchildren. Afterwards, we would make peach pizza using fresh peaches from my neighbor’s trees.

Images: (1) Chieko remembering back to when she and her grandchildren picked wildflowers and caught fireflies; (2) making peach pizza in her stone oven. 

 ***************************************************************************************************************

 We hope that others will be inspired to duplicate the Fukushima "Sidewalk Storybook" so that Japan can begin to receive the international support needed to address this unprecedented nuclear disaster.

This is a cautionary tale. Will we wait until a nuclear accident happens again or will we work to end the use of nuclear power world-wide? 

 ****************************************************************************************************************

Funds raised for this project will be used to:

1) Fund the artist's production of the images for the story

2) Produce edit and distribute the video

2) Recruit and organize chalk artists and volunteers

3) Fund sidewalk chalk event supplies 

4) Fund city permitting fees and clean-up

5) Donate 10% of the amount we raise to Fukushima Response

Our Team:

ARTISTS - Lia May-Byrd painted the beautiful image in the upper left corner of this page. http://www.liamay-byrd.com

(We are currently recruiting other artists to paint other images for this project. Please contact timothynonn@gmail.com if interested in participating.)

PROJECT DIRECTOR - Tim Nonn has an extensive background as a community organizer. As a leader in the Darfur Movement from 2004 to 2008, he organized a global arts and activism project called “Tents of Hope” in which over 400 cities painted simulated refugee tents, and then delivered them to refugees in Darfur. Tim is also a writer who has published poetry, short stories and essays. He has a doctorate in ethics from Graduate Theological Union. His favorite quote is by Thich Nhat Hahn: “To arrive at the ocean, you must go as a river.” 

PROJECT PRODUCER - Sonya Tafejian has a long history of community organizing in the areas of environment, housing, labor and human rights. She worked for the CA State Senate for a decade before joining an "energy efficiency" start-up in Petaluma. She co-founded Forty Oaks Co-Housing Community and established an organic textile business. She has a B.A. in political science and is a local (Sonoma Co.) activist. 

VIDEO DIRECTOR - John Bertucci is currently the Executive Director of Petaluma Community Access. PCA provides public access to television production equipment and training to produce and broadcast television shows made by and for the community. He has been making films and media since 1972, working for 15 years in Europe as a video documentary director. Stimulating and empowering the creativity of others is where and how he measures success. John is the founder of Fukushima Response.

Please make a donation of any amount to this project. The people of Japan need our help. Please help raise awareness on this issue which is most acute in Japan right now. We have only one ocean and one atmosphere to protect world-wide. Ten % of your donation goes to Fukushima Response. Please scroll to the top of the page and make a donation now. Thank you!

Images: (1) Chieko reunited with her daughter and grandchildren in Fukushima; (2) destroyed nuclear power plant in the background. 
Chapter Five
Story: Chieko grapples with the dilemma of living in Fukushima.
Text: In Fukushima we can’t do simple things like breathing deeply outside or drying laundry in the sun. We live in uncertainty. Who caused 3/11? Who’s responsible for what happened after 3/11? I wanted to see things for myself and figure out what we should do.
Image: Chieko walking through the town and countryside looking at ruined rice fields, forests, sick children, lost pets and other scenes of devastation. 
Chapter Six
Story: Chieko witnesses first-hand the danger and hardships faced by residents every day in Fukushima. She becomes an anti-nuclear power activist.
Text: After moving to Fukushima, I devoted myself to stopping nuclear power in Japan. I founded a group called Fukushima Women against Nuclear Power.
Image: A group of women in a building with a sign that reads, Fukushima Women against Nuclear Power.
Chapter Seven
Story: Chieko’s new organization starts a grocery store.
Text: We began noticing strange looking plants and deformed butterflies. The school’s pet rabbit had a baby born without ears. I worried our food was contaminated, so we opened a small grocery store selling vegetables from non-contaminated areas.
Images: (1) Deformed plants, butterfly and rabbit; (2) grocery store with healthy vegetables and happy customers.
Chapter Eight
Story: The children in Fukushima are suffering more than the adults. 
Text: Mothers are very worried about their children. They get nose bleeds, coughs, eye problems, and colds that don’t end. The impact of contamination is five times worse for children than for adults. Our group helps children relocate, but some can’t leave due to family complications and financial issues.
Images: (1) Children being evacuated; (2) children staying behind.
Chapter Nine
Story: Government and nuclear industry are covering up the dangers of radiation.
Text: The government opened clinics to help people worried about their health and radiation. But these patients are silenced when they go to the doctor’s office. They are told, “It’s not the radiation. The problem is you’re too stressed out.” (39 words)
Image: Government clinic with a sign that says high radiation levels are safe.
Chapter Ten
Story: Construction begins on a new community clinic.
Text: We built our own clinic because we don’t trust the government doctors. We need this clinic to save the lives of our children. We can’t rely on the government, and the media is not telling the truth. We have to make our own future.
Image: A new clinic under construction - a sign reads, “We want our children to live and be healthy!”
Chapter Eleven
Story: Chieko travels to the United States to build support for the people of Fukushima.
Text: We struggle, but we have to go on. As a woman, I believe we must continue to fight because our children’s lives are in danger. We women must fight for them and help to unite everyone.
Images: (1) Chieko speaking at a rally in California; (2) the crowd applauding and people holding signs calling for an end to nuclear power, “We love (heart) Fukushima,” etc.
Chapter Twelve
Story: Chieko remembers her former happy life in Fukushima before 3/11.
Text: I remember waking up every day to the sound of birds and looking forward to a good day. As an organic farmer, I felt one with nature. In the summertime, I would catch fireflies with my grandchildren. Afterwards, we would make peach pizza using fresh peaches from my neighbor’s trees.
Images: (1) Chieko remembering back to when she and her grandchildren picked wildflowers and caught fireflies; (2) making peach pizza in her stone oven. 
 ***************************************************************************************************************
 We hope that others will be inspired to duplicate the Fukushima "Sidewalk Storybook" so that Japan can begin to receive the international support needed to address this unprecedented nuclear disaster.
This is a cautionary tale. Will we wait until a nuclear accident happens again or will we work to end the use of nuclear power world-wide? 





 ****************************************************************************************************************
Funds raised for this project will be used to:
1) Fund the artist's production of the images for the story
2) Produce edit and distribute the video
2) Recruit and organize chalk artists and volunteers
3) Fund sidewalk chalk event supplies 
4) Fund city permitting fees and clean-up
5) Donate 10% of the amount we raise to Fukushima Response
Our Team:
ARTISTS - Lia May-Byrd painted the beautiful image in the upper left corner of this page. http://www.liamay-byrd.com
(We are currently recruiting other artists to paint other images for this project. Please contact timothynonn@gmail.com if interested in participating.)


PROJECT DIRECTOR - Tim Nonn has an extensive background as a community organizer. As a leader in the Darfur Movement from 2004 to 2008, he organized a global arts and activism project called “Tents of Hope” in which over 400 cities painted simulated refugee tents, and then delivered them to refugees in Darfur. Tim is also a writer who has published poetry, short stories and essays. He has a doctorate in ethics from Graduate Theological Union. His favorite quote is by Thich Nhat Hahn: “To arrive at the ocean, you must go as a river.” PROJECT PRODUCER - Sonya Tafejian has a long history of community organizing in the areas of environment, housing, labor and human rights. She worked for the CA State Senate for a decade before joining an "energy efficiency" start-up in Petaluma. She co-founded Forty Oaks Co-Housing Community and established an organic textile business. She has a B.A. in political science and is a local (Sonoma Co.) activist. 
VIDEO DIRECTOR - John Bertucci is currently the Executive Director of Petaluma Community Access. PCA provides public access to television production equipment and training to produce and broadcast television shows made by and for the community. He has been making films and media since 1972, working for 15 years in Europe as a video documentary director. Stimulating and empowering the creativity of others is where and how he measures success. John is the founder of Fukushima Response.

Please make a donation of any amount to this project. The people of Japan need our help. Please help raise awareness on this issue which is most acute in Japan right now. We have only one ocean and one atmosphere to protect world-wide. Ten % of your donation goes to Fukushima Response. Please scroll to the top of the page and make a donation now. Thank you!

story:
Boozhoo, Tansi, Hello,

Over three years ago, the Idle No More movement emerged and drew worldwide attention to issues impacting not only Indigenous people, but everyone living on Mother Earth. The movement’s vision became “to call on all people to join in a peaceful revolution, to honor Indigenous sovereignty, and to protect the land and water.” This movement continues to grow while providing support for Indigenous issues worldwide, such as Protecting Mauna Kea, Stopping Bill C-51, and Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women, Girls, and Two-Spirit Peoples.(MMIWG2S). As we continue to grow and move forward, more than ever we must focus on, and work with, solutions that will help create the change necessary and ensure the sustainability of future generations.

Goal: Our goal is to present at the Healing Our Spirit Worldwide conference being held November 15-19, 2015, in Hamilton, New Zealand. The conference attracts Indigenous elders, academics, and youth from around the world by providing a platform that allows them to share their unique Indigenous worldviews. 

Our presentation will use a solution-focused approach through nehiyaw and Anishinaabe laws. We will focus on food sovereignty and reclaiming our traditional ways to eating and living a healthy way of life. Our message is to learn to live off the land, become self-sustainable, and empower our communities to self-determination.

Our workshop proposal has been accepted by the conference committee. Now we need your support to help us get there.

Presenters
Sylvia McAdam (Saysewahum) is a nehiyaw lawyer and a co-founder of the Indigenous-led global movement Idle No More. She received a Law Degree from the University of Saskatchewan and a Human Justice Degree from the University of Regina. She is an advocate for Treaty, a speaker, an author, and a direct descendant of Treaty peoples. She recently released her book Nationhood Interrupted: Revitalizing nêhiyaw Legal System.

“Healing our Spirit Worldwide needs to hear our Indigenous voices to represent as Idle No More organizers. We believe we will bring a unique perspective by explaining that when we say “healing” we must also speak on behalf of those that have no voice; the animals, plants, waters, winged ones, and so forth, who are our relatives need healing as well. We have incorporated and interwoven their struggles in terms of land devastations, water contamination, and air pollution. Human healing is one aspect of a much bigger healing and protecting in this pivotal time in which all of creation faces a catastrophe. Our actions will unfold the future.”

Shawn Johnston is a Two-Spirit Anishinaabe originally from Couchiching First Nations located in Treaty #3 Territory. He recently graduated with his Masters in Social Work from Wilfrid Laurier University. He is currently the Events Coordinator for the Waterloo Aboriginal Education Centre located at the University of Waterloo. Shawn was recently honoured by Western University as the recipient of its Young Alumni Award. He accepts the award this fall.

“Being an organizer for Idle No More has allowed me to find my own voice and help advocate for others. It is my goal to continue educating others within my community about issues impacting the First Peoples of Turtle Island. I complete this work for my nieces and nephews, as well their children. I have felt the impact that assimilation by a so-called “government” has had on my community. I do not want to see this happen for our future generations and will do what I can to help protect the generations of today. There is so much work that we still need to do and in order for change to take place, we need to do this together.”

Where will the funds go?
The funds raised will help cover costs of our registration, travel, and meals for the duration of our stay. We estimate a total of $8280 is needed for both of us to attend this international gathering.

Return travel: Saskatoon, Canada, to Hamilton, New Zealand (Sylvia McAdam) $2250
Return travel: Toronto, Canada to Hamilton, New Zealand (Shawn Johnston) $2250
Accommodations for four nights $2000
Meals for five days ($40/day/person) $400
Registration ($690/person) $1380

TOTAL $8280

Impact:
The impact of Sylvia and Shawn’s involvement in this conference will be felt both by other conference attendees in Hamilton, New Zealand, and by members of their respective home communities. As leaders in both the global Idle No More movement and their local communities, Sylvia and Shawn will bring to the conference important grassroots understandings of the issues faced by Indigenous peoples on Turtle Island. This insight will contribute to and deepen the discussions at the international Healing Our Spirit Worldwide conference. In addition, the learning and relationships that Sylvia and Shawn will have the opportunity to develop while at the conference will contribute to their work in their home communities.

story:
On December 7th Typhoon Hagupit (locally known as Ruby) made landfall in the Eastern Visayas region of the Philippines, devastating the area. Early reports indicate the destruction of tens of thousands of homes, with some municipalities estimating 80% destruction. This area was heavily damaged when Super Typhoon Haiyan hit last year, killing over 6,000 people and leaving millions homeless. 

YPDR's Emergency Response Team is immediately deploying to Eastern Samar and we need your help to repair and rebuild destroyed homes.

For the last four months, YPDR has been running an existing housing project in Eastern Samar, so we have an existing infrastructure in place allowing us to begin delivering shelter solutions immediately. We have a team of twenty skilled carpenters, a construction yard, a logistics chain, and a proven typhoon-resistant housing design that withstood the power of Typhoon Hagupit. This means we can rapidly deliver shelter solutions for those affected in the area, quickly scaling up our operations.

YPDR has built more than 900 typhoon resistant shelters on Bantayan Island in the year since Typhoon Haiyan, all of which withstood the fury of Hagupit. These proven structures have been designed in conjunction with the University of San Carlos and have been endorsed by the United Nations's Shelter Cluster.

We are making an immediate and initial $125,000 to pay for materials and labor so that we can repair, strengthen, and rebuild the homes of the most vulnerable families. These funds will allow us to respond immediately at full strength and begin work within days.

For more information on Young Pioneer Disaster Response, visit our website www.ypdr.org, Facebook, www.facebook.com/YPDRYPDR, and Twitter, www.twitter.com/YoungPioneerDR.

story:
We need your help to save New Zealand’s largest organic heritage or heirloom Seed and Tree collection by 6th June 2014. We are asking for your support for this campaign to secure the land the New Zealand organic heritage seed collection grows on before we lose it.

Background: 30 years of organic heritage seed saving

Koanga Institute founded by Kay Baxter has spent 30 years building up a living library comprising of hundreds of heritage fruit and vegetables that are in danger of extinction and being lost. These seeds are either from New Zealand or brought here from England, Scotland, Croatia, Germany, France, South Africa, pacific islands and other parts of the world with our ancestors when they settled in New Zealand. Some of the seed lines do not exist any longer in their country of origin.

Kay says ‘Old people who sent us in their sacred seeds 30 years ago understood the sacredness of their seeds, that had been in their families for generations. The next generation was the generation that stopped gardening and they had no body to pass their seeds to.

We were all over the TV and media at that time Country Calendar etc and they saw us and their seeds began flowing into our mail box , with their stories and recipes in wobbly hand writing… we felt so humbled.


In 1994 the UN estimated that 94 percent of vegetables and 85 percent of apple varieties have already been lost and a further 3% of the remaining biodiversity was lost every year after that. Our ecologists tell us and we can see that life as we know it on earth is dependant on our biodiveristy and all the connections. With way less than 10% of the food plants we had 100 years ago we are on a knife edge right now!!


The Koanga Institute a registered charitable trust in New Zealand has saved 800+ seed lines and 400+ fruit trees and berries varieties. Some of these lines have international importance, particularly the corn collection, which is one of the largest collections not affected by genetic engineering, came here with our ancestors. This collection has many ecological and nutritional characteristics that will be invaluable for the future of regenerative agriculture and our health in New Zealand and potentially worldwide.  The home for this collection is in Wairoa, Northern Hawkes bay on leased land.  3 years ago Koanga Institute found the right land to literally and figuratively plant our roots. It took 5 years to find this land. This land has:

  • good soils and  water, a great climate for growing seeds
  • 3+ years of investment in the soil minerals and biology for growing nutrient dense seeds
  • enough area for our collections, growing areas, forest gardens, isolation gardens ( super important) and nursery,
  • isolation from horticulture and GE crops,
  • a large farmhouse, and several sheds, enough area to add several small cabins for interns and staff accommodation in the future,
  • a supportive community around us, the potential to develop a full campus to train future seed savers and gardeners to care for the next generations of heritage seeds and support regenerative agriculture in other communities, using the many models on our demonstration site to do that

Why are the seeds in danger on the 6th of June?

Koanga Institute does not own the land its organic heritage seed and tree collection is located on, it leases it. The current owners and mortgage holders want to sell it now. If Koanga Institute wants to buy the land it must come up with the funds by the 6th of June or be evicted with its heritage seed and tree collection on the 16th of July.

Whilst Koanga Institute can sustain its operational activities through seed sales and educational offerings, it does not have the capacity for such a large capital investment. The land asking price is NZD $705,000 (USD 609,000). Initially we were given to the 29th of June to raise the funds. This deadline has now been moved forward to the 6th of June. If we do not pay on the 6th of June we will be evicted on the 16th of July. This platform takes donations from USD10.00 which converts roughly to NZD12.90 and no extra fees. Please note this website pays out even if the full target is not reached. If the full target is not reached we will continue to search for other means to top up the fund.

We are doing everything in our power to raise funds from national speaking tours, national workshops, online crowd fundraising, looking for business sponsorship, offering memberships, but we need your help.So far we have raised USD129,000


Why are heritage or heirloom organic seeds so important?

We know from taste, our feelings and from science, that our heritage food plants contain the potential for providing us with far more nutrition than modern industrial food plants could. We can see the direct link between nutrient dense food and health, and between highly mineralized soils and health. Seeds before industrialization… were selected for

•  Local soils and environment, they did well in our own garden situations

•  Selected to nourish people

•  Selected to disease resistance and health in local environment

•  Taste, and usefulness in the kitchen

•  These seeds were all an amazing collection of genetic material, that nourished us, grow well in our soil and climate area, had the genetic blueprint to survive climate change.

•  Industrial system has selected for production, shelf life, toughness, harvesting all at once, and many other reasons. The responsibility of the system is to the shareholders, it is all about financial returns, they are not responsible to you and I and our health.

The implications of this are

•  Most of our seeds produce fruit, vegetables that are flavorless and uninviting. so they process it and add loads of fillers, homogenizers, colors and flavors and preservatives to make it taste better and sell better and make money

•  Many of our seeds contain enzyme blockers which mean they cannot pick up key minerals from the soil anymore, they can never be nutrient dense and we don’t get key minerals in our bodies i.e. manganese. Most hybrid seeds are like this. Organic food grown from hybrid seed (not organic or heirloom or heritage seed) will not contain these minerals any more than non-organic food

•  we cannot save our own seeds from these seeds

•  seeds bred and selected in the industrial system are bred to need industrial inputs

•  The implications of using seed that has been grown in soils that have been treated with round up or seeds that are RoundUp Ready GE seeds are large  and not life affirming. The latest information shows us that seeds grown in systems where glyphosate has been used carry the glyphosate in the seed, and the food grown from that seed, a for generation after generation and (glyohosate is patented as an anti microbial/ anti life  product). The implications for our health are enormous. 

About Koanga Institute

Kay Baxter realised the trees and seeds hold our stories, they tell us who we are! She began saving New Zealand heritage seeds after the nuclear disaster in Russia Chernobyl, when she realised our absolute vulnerability being almost totally dependant here in this land on seed from countries in the Northern hemisphere ( at that point under a nuclear cloud).

Kay with partner Bob Corker founded Koanga Institute. ‘We were simply acting on our gut feelings however after 25 years of living with these seeds, of growing them in our food gardens, and of them being all our children and now grandchildren know in their lives we have come to understand just ho every critical they are for our future’.

The F.A.O told us all 20 years ago that we had 10% of the vegie varieties left that we’d held in the world 100 years before that. They are still being lost at a rate of 3% a year,  that means in our estimation we’re really lucky if we have 3% left. Our ecologist tell us and it’s easy to see stat life as we know it depends upon diversity and integration. If we only have 3% or less of our for plants left  we’re not doing well and the implications are enormous. The knew science of epigenetics is also now showing us that our own heritage food plants communicate with our DNA more clearly than somebody else’s food , and that for our DNA to remain intact and not deteriorate we need certain levels of minerals and vitamins etc. The only food plants we have that were selected and held and grown to nourish us are those we co evolved with, our heritage food plants. They are our ancestors gift to us, they are our most precious Toanga (sacred treasure).

 

What others say about us

“Kay Baxter is a true eco-hero, I am a huge admirer of the work she has pioneered with the Koanga Institute to save and protect our seeds. Koanga Institute is a really unique trust; there is no other seed bank with organic heritage seeds like this in New Zealand.” 

- Malcolm Rands (Ecoman), founder and director of EcoStore.


“Kay Baxter Founder of Koanga Institute is one of the very best gardeners I have ever met and has made the most thorough detail study of heritage fruit trees and food plant seeds having been very active in saving local seed and fruit tree varieties, her knowledge through practical experience, and major achievements that have built a huge wealth of knowledge is way beyond anybody I know.

-Geoff Lawton, internationally recognised permaculture consultant, designer and teacher from Australia


Listen to what Joel Salatin (Polyface farms) and Nick Ritar (Milkwood) have to say  about saving the heritage seeds


Our latest Press

Heritage Seeds- Good Morning TVNZ, 20 August Famous foodie Peta Mathias reveals why she's joining forces with the Koanga Institute's Kay Baxter to help save our heritage seeds...see more

Saving our seed for the future – Seven Sharp TV1 15 November 2013 Modern produce has been bred for shelf life not taste, but there is a group of kiwis trying to bring back the… see more

Kiwis missing out on heritage food – Firstline TV3, 19 March 2014 Kay Baxter, director of the Koanga Institute, is on a mission to save New Zealand’s heritage seeds… watch

Feeding the nation: Are all fruits and veges created equal? – Element, NZ Herald 31 Jan 2014 In the final part of a three-part report on nutrition and poverty in New Zealand, experts weigh in on keeping pesticides to a minimum… see more

Plant your veges and watch savings grow – Hamilton News 8 June 2013 Sustainable gardening advocates the Koanga Institute say science supports what our tastebuds have been telling us: home-grown “heritage” vegetables are nutritionally superior to pesticide-ridden store-bought produce… see more

Gardening: Core of good health – Herald on Sunday 20 May 2012 Visit the supermarket and you’ll find only three or four types of apples to choose from at any given time, but New Zealand research of heritage varieties proves some older cultivars are worth holding on onto… see more

Kay Baxter on food foresting – Radio Live 25 JanuaryKay Baxter from the Koanga Institute talks food foresting with Tony Murrell… listen

Koanga Institute and Heritage Seeds – Radio NZ 24 November 2013 It isn’t widely known that a large proportion of the heritage fruit and vegetables on the planet have either passed into extinction or are rapidly headed that way… listen

A New Home for Koanga Institute and Gardens – Radio NZ 15 July 2011 For the past 25 years Kay Baxter and her husband Bob Corker have been saving New Zealand’s heritage fruit trees and vegetables at Koanga Gardens in Kaiwaka. But five years ago they decided they needed a new place to live so have found a new home near Wairoa where they’re developing a Community Land Trust which they hope will support up to 30 families…listen

How you can help

Share our campaign: think about passing it on to others who may wish to support it. We need your help. This is a matter of profound national significance – please join us in this vital investment in our food future! This IS a race against time. We would be honoured if you would help us promote our crowd fund raising campaign to your community and friends through e-mail, newsletters, blogs, facebook,  other social media or contacting the media to tell out story.

Donate via this site as part of a crowd fundraising donate

Contact us via email and let us know how you can help: can you run a fund-raising event, sponsor us, become a business member, or anything else that may help. Contact emma@koanga.org.nz

FAQS:

  • What happens to my money once I have donated? The money will be put into a secure trust account and only used for the purpose of buying the land.
  •  Is my donation tax deductible? Koanga Institute is a registered charity in New Zealand and donations are tax deductible.
  •  What are Koanga Institutes plans for the future? In addition this land will be used for research and the educational activities of the Koanga Institute to proactively promote the development of other seed saving organisations, community groups and train New Zealand’s future heritage gardeners and guardians.
