     gardens, isolation gardens ( super important) and nursery,
isolation from horticulture and GE crops,
a large farmhouse, and several sheds, enough
     area to add several small cabins for interns and staff accommodation in
     the future,
a supportive community around us, the potential to develop a full
     campus to train future seed savers and gardeners to care for the next
     generations of heritage seeds and support regenerative agriculture in
     other communities, using the many models on our demonstration site to do
     that
Why are the seeds in danger on the 6th of June?
Koanga
Institute does not own the land its organic heritage seed and tree collection is
located on, it leases it. The current owners and mortgage holders want to sell
it now. If Koanga Institute wants to buy the land it must come up with the
funds by the 6th of June or be evicted with its heritage seed and
tree collection on the 16th of July.
Whilst Koanga
Institute can sustain its operational activities through seed sales and
educational offerings, it does not have the capacity for such a large capital
investment. The land asking price is NZD $705,000
(USD 609,000). Initially we were given to the 29th of June to raise
the funds. This deadline has now been moved forward to the 6th of
June. If we do not pay on the 6th of June we will be evicted on the
16th of July. This platform takes donations from USD10.00 which converts roughly to NZD12.90 and no extra fees. Please note this website pays out even if the full target is not reached. If the full target is not reached we will continue to search for other means to top up the fund.
We are doing everything in our power to raise funds from national
speaking tours, national workshops, online crowd fundraising, looking for
business sponsorship, offering memberships, but we need your help.So far we have raised USD129,000Why are heritage or heirloom organic seeds
so important?
We know from taste, our feelings and
from science, that our heritage food plants contain the potential for providing
us with far more nutrition than modern industrial food plants could. We can see
the direct link between nutrient dense food and health, and between highly mineralized
soils and health. Seeds before industrialization… were selected for 
• 
Local soils and
environment, they did well in our own garden situations
• 
Selected to
nourish people
• 
Selected to
disease resistance and health in local environment
• 
Taste, and
usefulness in the kitchen
• 
These seeds
were all an amazing collection of genetic material, that nourished us, grow
well in our soil and climate area, had the genetic blueprint to survive climate
change. 
• 
Industrial system has selected for production, shelf life, toughness,
harvesting all at once, and many other reasons. The responsibility of the
system is to the shareholders, it is all about financial returns, they are not
responsible to you and I and our health.
The implications of this are
• 
Most of our seeds produce fruit, vegetables that are flavorless and
uninviting. so they process it and add loads of fillers, homogenizers, colors
and flavors and preservatives to make
it taste better and sell better and make money 
• 
Many of our seeds contain enzyme blockers which mean they cannot pick up
key minerals from the soil anymore, they can never be nutrient dense and we
don’t get key minerals in our bodies i.e. manganese. Most hybrid seeds are like
this. Organic food grown from hybrid seed (not organic or heirloom or heritage
seed) will not contain these minerals any more than non-organic food
• 
we cannot save our own seeds from these seeds
• 
seeds bred and selected in the industrial system are bred to need industrial
inputs
• 
The implications of using seed that has been grown in soils that have
been treated with round up or seeds that are RoundUp Ready GE seeds are
large  and not life affirming. The latest information shows us that seeds grown in
systems where glyphosate has been used carry the glyphosate in the seed, and
the food grown from that seed, a for generation after generation and
(glyohosate is patented as an anti microbial/ anti life  product). The implications for our health are
enormous. About Koanga Institute
Kay Baxter realised the trees and seeds hold our stories,
they tell us who we are! She began saving New Zealand heritage seeds after the
nuclear disaster in Russia Chernobyl, when she realised our absolute
vulnerability being almost totally dependant here in this land on seed from
countries in the Northern hemisphere ( at that point under a nuclear cloud).
Kay with partner Bob Corker founded Koanga Institute. ‘We
were simply acting on our gut feelings however after 25 years of living with
these seeds, of growing them in our food gardens, and of them being all our
children and now grandchildren know in their lives we have come to understand
just ho every critical they are for our future’. 
The F.A.O told us all 20 years ago that we had 10% of the
vegie varieties left that we’d held in the world 100 years before that. They
are still being lost at a rate of 3% a year, 
that means in our estimation we’re really lucky if we have 3% left. Our
ecologist tell us and it’s easy to see stat life as we know it depends upon
diversity and integration. If we only have 3% or less of our for plants
left  we’re not doing well and the implications are enormous. The knew
science of epigenetics is also now showing us that our own heritage food plants
communicate with our DNA more clearly than somebody else’s food , and that for
our DNA to remain intact and not deteriorate we need certain levels of minerals
and vitamins etc. The only food plants we have that were selected and held and
grown to nourish us are those we co evolved with, our heritage food plants.
They are our ancestors gift to us, they are our most precious Toanga (sacred
treasure).
  







What others say about us

“Kay Baxter is a true
eco-hero, I am a huge admirer of the work she has pioneered with the Koanga
Institute to save and protect our seeds. Koanga Institute is a really unique
trust; there is no other seed bank with organic heritage seeds like this in New
Zealand.”  
- Malcolm Rands (Ecoman), founder and director of EcoStore.
“Kay Baxter Founder of
Koanga Institute is one of the very best gardeners I have ever met and has made
the most thorough detail study of heritage fruit trees and food plant seeds
having been very active in saving local seed and fruit tree varieties, her
knowledge through practical experience, and major achievements that have built
a huge wealth of knowledge is way beyond anybody I know.
-Geoff
Lawton, internationally recognised permaculture consultant, designer and teacher from Australia
Listen to what Joel Salatin (Polyface
farms) and Nick Ritar (Milkwood) have to say  about saving the heritage seeds









Our latest Press
Heritage Seeds- Good Morning TVNZ, 20 August Famous foodie Peta Mathias reveals why she's joining forces with the 
Koanga Institute's Kay Baxter to help save our heritage seeds...see moreSaving our seed for the future – Seven Sharp TV1 15 November 2013 Modern produce has been bred for
shelf life not taste, but there is a group of kiwis trying to bring
back the… see
more
Kiwis missing out on heritage food – Firstline TV3, 19 March 2014 Kay Baxter, director of the
Koanga Institute, is on a mission to save New Zealand’s heritage seeds… watch
Feeding the nation: Are all fruits and veges created equal? – Element,
NZ Herald 31 Jan 2014 In the final part of a three-part report on nutrition and poverty in New
Zealand, experts weigh in on keeping pesticides to a minimum… see
more
Plant your veges and watch savings grow – Hamilton News 8 June 2013 Sustainable gardening advocates
the Koanga Institute say science supports what our tastebuds have been telling
us: home-grown “heritage” vegetables are nutritionally superior to pesticide-ridden
store-bought produce… see
more
Gardening: Core of good health – Herald on Sunday 20 May 2012 Visit the supermarket and you’ll
find only three or four types of apples to choose from at any given time, but
New Zealand research of heritage varieties proves some older cultivars are
worth holding on onto… see
more
Kay Baxter on food foresting – Radio Live 25 JanuaryKay Baxter
from the Koanga Institute talks food foresting with Tony Murrell… listen
Koanga Institute and Heritage Seeds – Radio NZ 24 November 2013 It isn’t widely known that a
large proportion of the heritage fruit and vegetables on the planet have either
passed into extinction or are rapidly headed that way… listen
A New Home for Koanga Institute and Gardens – Radio NZ 15 July 2011 For
the past 25 years Kay Baxter and her husband Bob Corker have been saving New
Zealand’s heritage fruit trees and vegetables at Koanga Gardens in Kaiwaka. But
five years ago they decided they needed a new place to live so have found a new
home near Wairoa where they’re developing a Community Land Trust which they
hope will support up to 30 families…listen
How you can help
Share our campaign: think about passing it on to others who may wish to support it. We
need your help. This is a matter of profound national significance – please
join us in this vital investment in our food future! This IS a race against
time. We would be honoured if you would help us promote our crowd fund raising
campaign to your community and friends through e-mail, newsletters,
blogs, facebook,  other social media or contacting the media to tell out
story.
Donate via this site as part of a crowd fundraising donate 
Contact us via email and let us know how you can help: can you run a fund-raising
event, sponsor us, become a business member, or anything else that may help.
Contact emma@koanga.org.nz
FAQS:

What
     happens to my money once I have donated? The money
     will be put into a secure trust account and only used for the purpose of
     buying the land. Is
     my donation tax deductible? Koanga Institute is a registered charity in
     New Zealand and donations are tax deductible. What
     are Koanga Institutes plans for the future? In addition this land will
     be used for research and the educational activities of
     the Koanga Institute to proactively promote the development of other
     seed saving organisations, community groups and train New Zealand’s future
     heritage
     gardeners and guardians.

story:
Innovation. Invention. Intervention

                                           

The international Wildlife Conservation Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) Challenge (wcUAVc) fosters innovation and invention in the design, fabrication, and utilization of unmanned aircraft or drones that emphasizes

  • integration of sensors
  • embedded systems
  • communications
  • open source 
 in a robust and high endurance aircraft, that assists with counter poaching and illicit wildlife trafficking of endangered species. The wcUAVc is the largest and most distributed aircraft research effort in the world with 139 teams in over 29 countries on 6 continents composed of students, hobbyists, academics, and corporations. 

                                                                                    

               

Kashmir-Robotics is the technology and wildlife security division of Kashmir World Foundation (KwF) who acquired the Technology Assisted Counter Poaching (TACP) network.  The network includes scientists and engineers with experience in countering poaching and trafficking of wildlife through application of sensors, communications, and computational technologies; and integrated robotics systems including unmanned aircraft and ground systems.

                       

The Global War Against Poaching

The rhino horn is one of the most valuable materials on Earth, worth more than six times the value of gold on the streets of Vietnam and China, where it is believed to have great medicinal power. Criminal networks linked to human, drug, and arms trafficking profit on this superstition, while environmentalists race to educate potential consumers about the fallacy of rhino horn medicine. The wcUAVc's innovative teams around the world are racing to invent the first counter poaching drones to prevent poachers from killing critically endangered species at risk of extinction.  South Africa's Kruger National Park is home to 73% of the world's rhino population where 3 rhinos are killed everyday.

 

         

 
Poachers are members of organized criminal networks, armed, trained, and ready for rigors of night fighting in the tough terrain of the African Bush. With about 400 rangers to patrol all of Kruger National Park, they need aircrafts that are tough, reliable, easy to repair, and able to perform their mission with relatively little human assistance.  Current military UAVs require more personnel for operation than manned aircraft. Achieving a breakthrough
  • in level of autonomy while driving costs down
  • requires leveraging new open source technology base
  • sensors 
  • processors
  • communications 
developed for smart phones and other personal electronic devices; and it requires innovation and invention in design, fabrication, and operation of aircraft.

The Challenge

The wcUAVc challenges the world to develop an unmanned aircraft able to fly day and night, independent of weather, and with a high degree of autonomy well beyond that of military aircraft - all under $3,000.
The 3-Tier Goal:
  • Create an awareness for endangered species worldwide.
  • Energize creative, innovative, and inventive people around the world to contribute towards a UAV that provides an immediate counter to ongoing poaching before the rhinos, elephants, and other endangered species become extinct.
  • Provide sustainable long-term strategic & tactical solutions for anti-poaching and wildlife trafficking through a collaboration of advanced integrated systems.

Counter Poaching Games

In the spring of 2015, teams competing in the wcUAVc around the world will travel to South Africa to demonstrate their aircraft's ability in a day and night simulated poaching scenario to detect and locate poachers through the integration of sensors, embedded systems, and communications able to relay accurate and timely intelligence to park rangers. 

                       



WE NEED YOUR HELP

In transitioning the innovative technology solutions to applications that will help save wildlife from extinction. We need your contributions to help facilitate wildlife conservation research and development efforts.
-Assessing technology requirements 
-Integrating training programs for park rangers
-Deploying technology solutions into the parks 
-Implement educational programs to help local communities sustain technology solutions
This is bigger than we anticipated so this will help us cover the costs for the counter poaching games and help support our competing teams in their travel to South Africa!

TEAMS COMPETING IN THE wcUAVc


 
Dutch UAS Team's automatic object detector... watch their unmanned aircraft tests with park rangers recently conducted in South Africa: www.dutchuas-tudelft.nl/tests-south-africa/ 



 Other Ways You Can Help!

Just because you can't contribute financially doesn't mean you can't help change the world and join our mission! 
  • Like us on Facebook: facebook.com/WildlifeConservationUAVChallenge
  • Follow us on Twitter:  twitter.com/WcUAVchallenge
  • Follow us on Instagram: instagram.com/wcuavc
  • Subscribe to us on Youtube: youtube.com/user/wcuavc/videos
  • Apply for an internship or volunteer opportunities with Kashmir World Foundation at www.kashmirworldfoundation.org to donate your time, skills, and talents. 
  • Spread the word, share the campaign, and speak up against the illegal poaching and trafficking of our world's exotic endangered species. 
* All perks will be delivered after the campaign is over. Perks related to the Counter Poaching Games will be delivered after the event has taken place.
Sponsors & Partners

story:
Who We Are & What We're Doing

My name is Marcelina Cravat and I am directing an important documentary film called Angel Azul that addresses the serious threats currently facing the world's coral reefs with particular focus on the Mesoamerican Reef located off the coast of the Yucatán Peninsula. Producing this film are Kath Delaney and Erik Johnson. The film follows the inspired work of eco/sculptor Jason deCaires Taylor who casts cement statues from live human models and installs them on the ocean floor in an underwater museum which over time grows into coral reefs! These artificial reefs serve many functions. They aggregrate fish, provide homes for other forms of marine life, provide a substrate for coral, act as a barometer for pollution in the surrounding water and help provide a reprieve for the natural reefs that are struggling from over use. The very distinguished Peter Coyote will be narrating our film! We are still pinching ourselves over that one! 

Why We Are Doing This

Because the situation is so dire, and because there is such a short window of time to try and save one of the ocean's most important and dying ecosystems, we are intent on promoting awareness  and inspiration for individuals to act. Information will be delivered through the expertise of scientitsts and professionals in the field of marine conservation. This includes the director of the Ecological Center in Akumal, Paul Sanchez-Navarro who works tirelessly to protect the precious Akumal Bay where sea turtles have been coming since forever to lay their eggs, and marine biologist Dr. Thomas Goreau, President of the Global Coral Reef Alliance. The many causes effecting the die-off of the reefs at such startling rates and solutions that could reverse this will be explored in our film. 

Where We Are

Our hauntingly beautiful underwater footage was shot by Mario Navarro and Jason deCaires Taylor himself! Our culturally rich and personal on land filming was shot by myself and Mario Navarro mostly in fishing villages and small towns along the Mayan Riviera. Our good friends at Sigma have supplied us with great quality lenses to do the job and they have! With just one production trip remaining, we are well underway with post production. This is currently the focus of our fundraising efforts as the tasks are numerous and depend on the talent and skills of a variety of professionals. From music to graphics, sound design to color correction, we are pushing ahead to complete what we've started! We cannot wait to bring it to you!

Tokens of Thanks

Tokens of thanks will be offerred for donations of any size. We are very grateful for monetary contributions to pay for the completion of Angel Azul and present it to viewers around the world, but we are also grateful for spreading the word. This means sharing the project with friends that might not have occasion to learn about it, and to also give thought to ways that we as individuals could reduce our carbon footprint so that we protect the precious resources that are so strained and so necessary to our existence.

story:
Microplastics researcher Dr. Sherri Mason, a speaker at Save The River's Winter Environmental Conference earlier this year, has had an equipment loss that cripples her ability to conduct much needed research on microplastics in the Great Lake and the St. Lawrence River. Her research into this emerging threat has proven pivotal in the basin-wide effort to ban these tiny, toxin accumulating ingredients used in many personal care products. 

Dr. Mason and Save The River need your assistance to keep the effort to understand and eliminate the threat of microplastics afloat.

Dr. Mason's microplastic samples are taken using a net called a Manta Trawl. These nets are specially designed to float on the surface of the water, where the majority of the plastics accumulate. Unfortunately, as part of a recent shipboard science expedition, her manta trawl met with an untimely demise. It was sucked under the ship where it became tangled in the motor wheel and sank to the bottom of the Lake Erie.

Dr. Mason and her team cannot continue their ground-breaking work without a manta trawl. Save The River and many other organizations, including the New York State Attorney General, rely on her research in our efforts to ban microplastics.

Her first trawl was purchased in 2012 as part of the first-ever expedition for plastic pollution in the Great Lakes. Over the past three summers it has collected samples in all five of the Great Lakes, as well as the St. Lawrence River. These samples have shown that plastic pollution in Lakes Erie, Ontario and the St. Lawrence River have some of the highest counts of any place in the world sampled to-date - including the oceans.

Understanding the extent and impact of microplastic pollution and enacting effective bans requires scientific research, and diligent, focused advocacy based on that research.
 
Save The River is asking for your help to replace Dr. Mason’s Manta Trawl and to ban microplastics from our Lakes and River.

Please make a donation today so Dr. Mason can replace this critical piece of equipment. Each Trawl is made on demand at a cost of $3,500. That's our goal. Any additional money raised to be used in our efforts to secure a basin-wide ban of these harmful products.

More about Dr. Mason’s work:  Why Those Tiny Microbeads In Soap May Pose Problem For Great Lakes      

Save The River speaks out about microplastic pollution

Thank you for your help in keeping this important research afloat and keeping the equally import effort to ban microplastics alive.

story:
Vote with your dollar - Help a Nation! The money will go to the Collective Effort Fund for global projects development. It is supported by the United Non-Profit Organizations. Money will be given for the needs of the Pilot Project, created by the Collective Effort. This is → Collaborative Currency (CC) and Direct Democracy (DD) -  applied together for a free Nation - Project Bulgaria for short. The mission of this initiative is to create Balance and spread it to the World.  

It is meant to help The People of Bulgaria overcome the political and severe economic crisis experienced right now. The government resided and the country is now floating in a void as people have no money to pay their electricity bills and at the same time they don’t trust neither political party nor representatives. People on the streets want direct participation in governing the country and also decent earnings to cover their basic needs.

Part of the money collected will go for the building of an online and offline infrastructure. It will allow people with internet or without to have an easy access to a secure and trustworthy way to create and engage with projects and decision making. For example - establishing local offices for discussion and voting; building and mainaining a first class security online system.  


Decisions will be made by applying direct democracy to the best possible extent. The money raised will will allow the Bulgarian Nation to establish the infrastructure for an open, global and interconnected marketplace. It will be supported online and offline and will implement the collaborative currency. The infrastructure will include an online marketplace connecting both currencies - online and offline, POS terminals in local businesses and digital signatures to just name a few. Suggestions are welcome from the whole World. 

GIVE $1. MAKE THIS VIRAL!
story_txt:
Vote with your dollar - Help a Nation! The money will go to the Collective Effort Fund for global projects development. It is supported by the United Non-Profit Organizations. Money will be given for the needs of the Pilot Project, created by the Collective Effort. This is → Collaborative Currency (CC) and Direct Democracy (DD) -  applied together for a free Nation - Project Bulgaria for short. The mission of this initiative is to create Balance and spread it to the World.  It is meant to help The People of Bulgaria overcome the political and severe economic crisis experienced right now. The government resided and the country is now floating in a void as people have no money to pay their electricity bills and at the same time they don’t trust neither political party nor representatives. People on the streets want direct participation in governing the country and also decent earnings to cover their basic needs.

Part of the money collected will go for the building of an online and offline infrastructure. It will allow people with internet or without to have an easy access to a secure and trustworthy way to create and engage with projects and decision making. For example - establishing local offices for discussion and voting; building and mainaining a first class security online system.  
Decisions will be made by applying direct democracy to the best possible extent. The money raised will will allow the Bulgarian Nation to establish the infrastructure for an open, global and interconnected marketplace. It will be supported online and offline and will implement the collaborative currency. The infrastructure will include an online marketplace connecting both currencies - online and offline, POS terminals in local businesses and digital signatures to just name a few. Suggestions are welcome from the whole World. 
GIVE $1. MAKE THIS VIRAL!

story:
We have planned 2 bag packs at our local supermarket, . The vast majority of our squad have been together 2-3 years and all attend schools in the croydon areas, with Elmhurst School for Boys being the majority. We have coached this squad voluntarily since the very beginning and through our own hard work over these years we have kept the nucleus of the team together. Most of our past and current squad members are all residents in croydon and as some of you may be aware croydon has a lot of social housing and a lot of run down council estates where most of our players come from. Each year through our own fundraising we have managed (only just) to provide the boys with a new kits, although this has been funded by sponsorship through connections from ourselves most of the time we have still had to purchase other essential football equipment. We have always taken the squad away at the end of every season to either Butlins on a UK soccer camp or Flamingo Land for a weekend camping. This provides some of the squad the only chance to leave croydon on what they would consider a holiday. We believe that this trip would help them not only socially but also on the acedemic aspects aswell. We hope this covers all our hopes and aims and gives you an insight into what we hope to achieve and that you can help towards this goal. We are very passionate about this squad as keeping them together playing football and having a bit of structure is keeping them from hanging about on the streets and maybe getting themselves into trouble or worse.

What We Need & What You Get

 

  • we aim to raise the £990. needed in order to complete the funding for this tour
  • All donators will be offer unlimited access to each and everyone of our games free of charge for the duration of the neww season

Thank for reading, and thanks in advance for your donations

story:
About us

 

The Mesoamerican Permaculture Institute (Instituto Mesoamericano de Permacultura – IMAP) is a non-profit organization based in Guatemala. It was founded in 2000 by a group of local Indigenous people concerned by the serious environmental, social and cultural problems affecting the nation. They established an ecological education center to promote permaculture techniques, local biodiversity conservation, production of organic food, and a seed bank that strives to reconstruct the Mayan seed heritage.


 

Why are we doing this?

 

Food sovereignty is integrally linked to seed sovereignty. Amidst increasing concerns about malnutrition, control of plant genetic resources and widespread dependancy on export-oriented agriculture in Guatemala, a demand has emerged for ways to revive the free exchange of seeds, to support smallholder farmers in their efforts to use native seeds, promote biodiversity as well as to ensure the conservation of ancestral values and agriculture techniques.

Ancestral knowledge and experience shows that farmer seed circulation is particularly important for building viable and diverse crop systems, and for ensuring a steady geographic distribution of local seed varieties. In Guatemala, native and heirloom seeds are not sold in stores, nor can they be ordered through catalogue. Seed growers are scattered throughout Guatemala with little possibility for exchanging seeds and sharing knowledge. While there are various organizations working in food security and agricultural sustainability, there is as of yet no unified effort for the promotion of native seeds in Guatemala.

We consider that seed networks, seed fairs and seed conferences are some of the most effective vehicles for seed circulation. They exist to serve the needs of farmers in terms of accessibility, cost, social relationship building and – perhaps most importantly – they foster local farmer agency. They serve as a unifying force in the struggle for food and seed sovereignty.


 

How will we do this?


 

1) By hosting a native seed conference uniting seed savers from 10 countries across the Americas(Red Semillas de Libertad).

2) By the creation of a national seed network (Guardianes de Semillas Guatemala).

This is why to  achieve this, we are setting our donation goal at $10,000.

 

Help us sow the seeds for a better future. 


 

How will your donation help?

 

Your donations will make it possible for us to sponsor and bring together farmers and seed producers from 10 different countries in the americas. In addition, funds will help us organize all the logistics involved in organizing this summit and the creation of the national seed network.

Some of the work entails promotion, management of registrants, coordination of speakers and presenters, organization of on-site details (food, lodging, speaking and music venues), implementation of a conference program ( including Seed Fair, debate circles, cultural program).  
 

What will be the long term impact of your support?

 

The mesoamerican permaculture institute  with the help of the seed freedom network (Red Semillas de Libertad) will create a national seed network (Red Guardianes de semillas Guatemala).

This national network will increase the ability of communities to protect their seeds to ensure the supply of native organic and heirloom seeds, which  are vital for the continuity of life.

 

Thank you for being part of the change

story:
If you pay in advance for next year's stay, we can pay off the park's debt at the same time -- showing the council that there is a demand for this place to stay open for next year! It's like a cash advance to the park. 

// BACKGROUND

Sioux Narrows-Nestor Falls municipal council wants to shut down the Sioux Narrows Provincial Park (SNPP), because they consider it a burden to taxpayers.

One councillor, Wayne Helliar, stated that "we should not be spending taxpayer dollars to run a business that competes with private enterprise."

We think that this is unsound logic on the part of folks like Mr. Helliar. In the words of the council Mayor, "it's like cutting off your nose to spite your face." 

ABOUT THE PARK

Sioux Narrows Provincial Park is a beloved camping spot for thousands of individuals and families, including many regulars from Winnipeg. 

The park is operated by the municipality, but the land is owned by Ontario's Ministry of Natural Resources.

The park is frequented by loyal patrons year after year because it offers: 

  • a unique, pristine natural setting teeming with wildlife
  • excellent management that ensures a quiet, family-friendly atmosphere
  • several private campsites, hiking trails, a beach, and boat launch
  • close proximity to the town of Sioux Narrows and its businesses

OTHER PARK CLOSURES

As part of a new trend in Ontario, the provincial government closed Caliper Lake Provincial Park last year -- to the continuing disapproval of businesses in nearby Nestor Falls. Sioux Narrows is the only provincial park left in the region, and it's run by the municipal government. 

UNSOUND PLANNING 

We think that this is unsound economic planning on the part of the council; that they're not fully considering the revenue the park tourists contribute to the community when they buy fishing licences, gas, and food at local restaurants. 

Since nearby private campgrounds do not offer the same unique features as SNPP, it's unlikely to think that patrons of the provincial park will flock to these so-called "competitor" campgrounds. Instead, the town will likely lose the traffic and business associated with the park’s tourist population.

New "attractions" such as the sparsely frequented Sportfishing Centre (at a total cost of $726,000.00 to the community) will likely prove to be a bigger year-over-year drain on tax revenue.

 

// WHAT WE WANT TO DO

First, we want to help pay off the park's modest $50,000.00 debt. The target amount of $53,500.00 includes fees payable to Indiegogo.

If about 500 people donate $100.00 (or 1000 people donate $50.00), we will have paid off the park's debt, removing this as an excuse to close the park! 

Second, we want to help the park restructure and promote so that it can stay open for many years to come.

Third, we will encourage the Province of Ontario to transfer operations of the park to a new non-profit Community Land Trust (CLT) specifically set up to manage the park.  

If the municipality closes the park anyway, a new Community Land Trust will invest the money in an ongoing campaign to keep the park open, or re-open the park after its closure. If this campaign fails, we will undertake to create a private park that retains the characteristics of Sioux Narrows Provincial Park.

 

// HOW MUCH WE NEED TO DO IT

If we raise anything up to $53,500, we will help pay off the park's operating line of credit.

If we raise $60,000-80,000, we will help the park restructure and promote. We will also ask Ontario's Provincial Government to transfer operations of the park from the municipality to a new non-profit Community Land Trust (CLT) set up to run the park over the long-term. 

If we raise $80,000+ we will set up a foundation dedicated to the ongoing management of Sioux Narrows Provincial Park by a new CLT. 

 

// WHAT YOU GET

As a Sioux Narrows enthusiast, we will credit you with a stay at the campground with your donation of $50.00 or more. It's like a cash advance to the park. 

Remember, if roughly 500 people donate $100.00 (or 1000 people donate $50.00), we will have paid off the park's debt! 

Your favourite campground has a chance at staying open for many years to come. 

 

// THE BROADER IMPACT

Setting up a Community Land Trust (CLT) could set a precedent for how public assets can be maintained in the years to come as governments face cash crunches and make poor investments. 

CLTs have been in existence for centuries, and have been experiencing a renaissance over the last fifty years due to the need for new tools to restore, operate, and develop public assets such as parks -- on a financially sustainable basis.

Under a “land first” operation strategy, they have proven successful tools for maintaining and operating public assets that local governments have otherwise had difficulty operating during this period of economic deregulation.

 

// OTHER WAYS TO HELP

SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN widely to help raise funds for the park

CLICK HERE TO SEND A LETTER to the municipal council expressing that you don't want this municipality to shut down this world-class park!

story:
Short Summary

 First I'd like to take a minute and thank each and every one of you who chose to click on the link that someone was willing to share. Just being here signifies that you're interested in some capacity. And it's appreciated! 

This campaign started out as a goofy suggestion to a teacher at the high school. Mentioning how awesome it would be to see those great, tall trees of the northwest towering over the school grounds. Something no other school district had. Something special, almost magical. When it was responded to with positivity and enthusiasm for follow through, a few of us got together to make some calls and do some 'homework'. Every time we dug a little deeper, everything pointed to the facts that these trees can, and would survive here in West Michigan. We had our hopes confirmed when we were told of two Giant Sequoias growing at the Lake Bluff Bird Sanctuary in Manistee.  The manager of the sanctuary confirmed the planting of the trees in 1962 and has been growing healthy since then. Reaching up to 250' tall, and trunks as large as 30' in diameter, these wonderful trees would create such an amazing spectacle! And that's what we are trying to accomplish with this campaign. To bring these amazing and majestic specimens here to Greenville, for our students and residents to admire.  We're hoping to raise enough money to bring these giants here and provide them with the long term care they'll need to grow up tall and strong for generations to come.

(Michigan Champion Giant Sequoia, Lake Bluff Bird Sanctuary)

The Dawn Redwood tree is known for growing to heights of 120' tall. It is considered a deciduous evergreen tree as they are one of a very few 'pine' trees to drop their needles in the late fall, just as trees with leaves do. It will eventually mimic the trees around it, turning bright orange and red in the cooler months of autumn. Dropping them around Halloween, and then sprouting new foliage in the spring as the earth warms their branches and melts the snow. 

(Dawn Redwood shot on 10/3/2011)



What We Need 

We're asking for $2,250. That will be broken down as follows:

  • $742.50/33% Tree Purchase
  • $450.00/20% Environmental Protection/Vandalism Prevention
  • $562.50/25% Project Supplies, i.e. stakes, compost, fencing, nutrients, water rings
  • $495.00/22% Long Term Care. (These trees will require annual maintenance for 5-7yrs. Including the removal of nearby grass, new compost/nutrients, etc.)
Every dollar counts. Contributions in any amount are accepted and appreciated. These trees cannot be purchased, planted in a hole, and forgotten about. They will require maintenance and attention each and every year for several years to come.

The Impact

Aside from being an attraction just as they stand alone, these trees can serve other purposes as well.  

  • Already utilizing the solar power tied into the grid from the school, these large trees absorb Co2 from our air, reducing the carbon footprint of the high school even further. A Giant Sequoia can take in as much 3.5 tons of carbon a year. That's up to 17.5 tons of carbon scrubbed from our oxygen just from the 5 Giant Sequoia trees alone! We haven't even calculated for the Dawn Redwoods!
  • Growing between 100'-250' and spanning as much as 100' wide, these trees will create an abundance of natural shade for spectators at the athletic events, keeping everything and everyone around them cooler during the hotter months.
  • These big trees will make phenomenal windbreaks. Ever stood towards the top of the stands at Legacy field? Can you feel that never-ending, forever chilly breeze cascading up and over the west fence? In a few years, these trees will break up the wind that picks up momentum coming across the entire athletic complex, reducing it's force by up to two thirds. There will also be trees placed to break up the winds near the tennis courts and Yellow Jacket Stadium.

Risks & Challenges

Because these trees are considered 'shallow rooted', Giant Sequoias cannot be near grass. It will keep the tree from getting sufficient water and nutrients, killing the tree within a few months. They will require care on a monthly basis for the first couple years, followed by quarterly maintenance thereafter for another 3-5 years, until the trees are big enough to cast enough shade that naturally hinders the grass growth.

  • Giant sequoias are shallow rooted. They require lots of attention for the first 24 months;  This project will require a team of volunteers to help with the trees a couple times a year for the next 5-7yrs. This require resources and man hours. All of which we have planned for here.
  • Giant Sequoias can be 'finicky' for the first 3-5yrs of their life. Environmental changes and shock can cause the trees the stop growing, or even die off.  We have been in contact with several individuals and organizations who have successfully raised Giant Sequoias, both here at Lake Bluff Bird Sanctuary, and in the Pacific Northwest.  They have been a tremendous help thus far, and have offered to assist with knowledge and troubleshooting whenever needed. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't make a contribution right now? That doesn't mean you can't help!  Speaking the word about this campaign far and wide is almost as good as cash!  Please, PLEASE take a moment to share this campaign on your social media pages and profiles, and do it often. Get your friends and family to share the campaign as well. Every face that sees it, is a potential contributor.  We thank you for your help. After that, there are other ways to chip in:

  • We will need volunteers! Help with moving the trees, planting the trees this spring, and maintaining the trees through the summer and fall. And then again next year. And the next year. And the year after that!  Want to help?  It would make for an AWESOME family event. Bring the kids! Let's get them involved, watch them grow up together.
  • Resources! If you have anything that might be of use to a couple people trying to raise giant trees, (landscape supplies, commercial truck, etc), please be sure to drop us a line! It will surely come in handy when it comes to plant.


THANK YOU to everyone who has made this a possibility. And thank you to everyone who has made a contribution in some way. It's humbling to see a community come together and make 'make an idea grow'!

story:
(Version Francaise sous le texte anglais)

SSS Phuket have decided to create the Coral Reef Creation Project in Thailand to fight against the threats (pollution, boats, human activity, global warming, fishing…) which are causing the marine environment to deteriorate. 

We have the know- how to restore coral reefs. We did some research on restoration and underwater tests. We would be working closely and  in cooperation with the Thai government to create a brand new area of natural coral reef in Kata Beach. 

 Before we go any deeper into the subject, we have to emphasize that NO damage is done to the environment: We would not use any kinds of machineries and we would not destroy or kill anything. 

Brief description of our restoration method:  

> First, we would create steel structures and sink them underwater. 

> Secondly, we would plant the coral pieces onto the structures.   

> Thirdly, we would make sure the first links of the food chain are found inside the artificial reef.

> Next, we would then monitor the reef once a week to monitor the coral’s development . The implementation would take around 2 weeks.  Within 6 months, a full-fledged marine ecosystem would be created with a healthy reef and a complete food chain. 

SSS Phuket is a PADI Scuba Diving and Surfing center and we have a dedicated team for the project to take care of all the settlement and the progressive monitoring. 

Time is ticking , and we urge each and everyone of you to play a part to protect the marine environment and to preserve the beauty of Phuket’s reef for the many generations to come.

(French Version)

Nous avons décidé de créer la Creation de Récif Corallien en Thaïlande afin de lutter contre tous les facteurs qui le menace (pollution, bateaux, activité humaine, réchauffement climatique, pêche…). 

L’environnement marin est fortement endommagé. Nous savons comment restaurer les récifs coralliens. Nous avons déjà effectué des études à propos de la restauration ainsi que des tests sous-marins.

Nous allons travailler en coopération avec le gouvernement thaïlandais afin de mener à bien notre projet a Kata Beach. Avant que vous n’alliez plus loin dans la lecture de notre programme, nous tenons à vous assurer qu’aucun dommage d’aucune nature ne sera causé sur l’environnement : nous n’utilisons pas de machine et nous ne détruirons ni ne tuerons ni la faune, ni la flore.

Brièvement, voici la méthode que nous allons employer :

> En premier lieu, nous allons créer des structures en acier et les fixer sur le fond marin.

> Nous allons ensuite transplanter des coraux sur ces structures. L’acier utilisé ainsi que les coraux ne feront qu’un.

> La troisième étape consiste à s’assurer que les premiers maillons de la chaîne alimentaire se trouvent bien dans le récif artificiel.

> Durant la partie suivante, nous contrôlons le récif mis en place chaque semaine dans le but de favoriser le développement du corail lui-même. Cette mise en œuvre va prendre environ 2 semaines. L’écosystème marin sera créé à part entière en 6 mois. La chaîne alimentaire est complète, le récif est en pleine santé et les abris sont assurés.

Nous sommes le centre de plongée SSS Phuket, de ce fait nous pouvons fournir toute la main d’œuvre nécessaire pour ce projet, et c’est pourquoi nous voulons prendre en charge l’installation et le contrôle des opérations effectuées. 

Le temps est compté mais nous savons que nous avons une chance de redonner à la Thaïlande par le biais de Phuket sa splendeur d’antan.

story:
Who is the Hell's Kitchen Farm Project?

Recognizing a need for better access to affordable and nutritious food in the community, especially for its low-income residents, Rauschenbusch Metro Ministries (RMM), Metro Baptist Church, Clinton Housing Development Company (CHDC), and Metropolitan Community Church of New York (MCCNY) organized in 2010 around a solution: a rooftop farm.

5 years later, HKFP has provided thousands of pounds of fresh vegetables to low-income residents in a community that has less and less affordable options for nutritious food and engaged hundreds people worldwide in sustainable farming, nutrion education and food justice advocacy.  On any given day of the week, you can now find an intergenerational group of volunteers growing and learning on a previously underused 4,000 square foot NYC, children getting their hands dirty as they cultivate compost, and community members picking up their weekly Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) share from our partner farmer in New Jersey.

Over the past few seasons, HKFP has fulfilled a community need for better access to healthy food. However, its successes reach much further. Its programming has been inclusive of the neighborhood’s diverse population, fostering a sense of community among participants. Its design reduces environmental impact, as the beds capture rainwater runoff before it falls to the sidewalks below. Its use of inexpensive kiddie pools offers a model for others to look to for inspiration and replication. HKFP illustrates that much can be achieved by getting your hands dirty. 

What We Need & Why We Need You:

We're asking for $2000 to increase the impact of HKFP by: 

  • Increasing our growing space beyond the 52 kiddie pools to railing planters and lightweight felt pots (thereby providing more fresh produce for our community food pantry).
  • Providing more educational programming for community children and youth.
  • Offering a teen internship program.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out about this campaign by using Indiegogo's simple social media share buttons!
  • Volunteer with us (check out our website: www.hkfp.org)
  • Sign up for a CSA share on our website.

story:
Why You Should Contribute

We’ve reached our initial goal which is going to help pay for production. Now any funds raised are going to go to the River Keepers to distribute to libraries and second grade teachers in our local watersheds. So additional contributions can make a difference to put this message in front of children.

My name is Sam Love and if you hate roadside plastic bags that can get into our food chain as much as I do this is your chance to fund the centerpiece of a children’s educational campaign on this critical issue.

Plastic in our oceans and inland waters is becoming a crisis. You’ve seen the alarming pictures of the massive floating plastic gyres in the ocean but even worse is that most of the plastic in the ocean is now broken down into such small pieces we don’t even see them. The tragedy is that marine animals are devouring the petrochemicals and they are getting into the food chain. We are only now understanding the environmental impact of this. I believe education can play an important role in making people more aware of the problem so I’m launching an Indiegogo campaign to fund a children’s book, My Little Plastic Bag, that will be the centerpiece for a campaign that can build awareness about this critical issue. Supporting this campaign is your chance to do something about it.

Just consider this one fact. A United Nations study found over 46,000 pieces of plastic per square mile in many parts of the ocean.

In the child friendly pictures and story we see a plastic bag tossed out by a careless child. No one picks it up and it is cut into small slivers by a mower. The pieces wash into a stream, an estuary and the ocean. As sunlight and the tides break up the plastic, smaller fish and other sea creatures ingest the tiny bits. Bigger fish eat the smaller fish and the chemicals concentrate up the food chain until the plastic comes back to the family as fish on their dinner plate.

Where did the book idea come from?

I was on the national staff of the first Earth Day and I have worked over the years with numerous environmental campaigns. My articles on energy and the environment have been published in magazines such as Smithsonian and now I write poetry that highlights the cracks in our culture.

The idea for this children’s book came from my poem “The Downstream Loop” in my book Converging Waters.  It traces the flow of a plastic bag through the ecosystem until the chemicals come back to a family’s dinner plate. Duke University’s Nicholas School of the Environment featured it in an issue of their wonderful environmental magazine Eno. Several people suggested it could make a children’s story so I am now working with Samrae Duke, an accomplished illustrator, to simplify the poem’s language and create compelling illustrations. It will be perfect for reading to children 4 to 8. 

It will  educate them on two important ecological concepts:

1. There is no away. 

2. There are cycles in nature.

This will give teachers and parents a great teaching tool to build awareness of environmental stewardship. It will be available for sale through book distribution channels including Amazon. To make sure the message gets out I am partnering with my local River Keepers group to place copies in the hands of every children’s librarian and second grade teacher in our North Carolina watershed if enough funds are raised. With your help we can make this happen.

By backing this campaign, you'll not only preorder this beautiful and informative book to share with your family or friends, but you will help bring to life this educational campaign about the damage we are doing to the Earth’s waters. Each and every pledge helps make this possible.

The goal of this Indiegogo project is to raise money for the first phase of the project, which is paying for production of the book. Additional funds will be used to provide free copies to the River Keepers for distribution to schools and libraries.

About Samrae Duke the Illustrator

Samrae Duke is a professional illustrator whose work has appeared in numerous publications and juried art exhibitions. She has a BFA in Studio Art with a concentration in Illustration from East Carolina University School of Art and Design.

Risks and challenges

I do not anticipate any major risks or challenges. The copy and approximately 40 percent of the illustrations are done. I have edited two nonfiction environmental books with major publishers and self-published two novels and two poetry books. I will manage the production timeline. It will be available by late spring of 2016 through traditional distributors including Amazon.

story:
"Happiness is a butterfly, which when pursued, is always just beyond your grasp, but which, if you will sit down quietly, may alight upon you."                                                                                          - Nathaniel Hawthorne

Let's Talk.

Think back to your childhood.  We all chased a butterfly in a field or down the sidewalk at some time or another, right?  Most likely, one of those butterflies was a Monarch butterfly; they used to be one of the most commonly seen and recognized butterflies of all. In fact, some call the Monarch the King of the Butterflies.  All hail the Monarch!

Here's the catch: In the past two years, according to Monarch Watch, the Monarch butterfly population has declined at a rate of 82%, a figure catching everyone by surprise.  

You might be asking yourself, “Why?”  Good question!

There are a few different factors to consider:

  1. Climate change, which affects everything, is also affecting the butterflies.  Wildfires, droughts, and floods are ruining all of the places Monarchs need to be.
  2. Deforestation in Mexican forests. After the Monarchs have made the 1,500+ mile journey across Canada and the United States, they expect to have a nice, relaxing winter in the picturesque Michoacan mountains in Mexico, the one place every single one of their ancestors has wintered.  But what’s this?  Thousands of acres of these woods are simply no longer there.
  3. Disappearing breeding habitat.  Once the Monarchs start to thaw out (literally!), they begin the trek north to pass along their amazing history to their future generations.  They expect to be able to lay eggs on Milkweed plants all along the journey – in Texas, Iowa, Toronto, and everywhere in between – but lately, have found the plant destroyed.  The main reason for this recent decline is because of the widespread use of glyphosates, like Roundup, which kills everything in its path except genetically modified crops (soybean and corn, mainly) immune to the deadly herbicide.  Without milkweed along the way, adult monarchs have nowhere to lay their eggs.  You might suggest they just lay the eggs elsewhere, but the milkweed plant is the only thing the baby larva eat to survive.  The loss of the milkweed plant is detrimental to the survival of the Monarch species on many levels.

Why is This Important?

The loss of the milkweed and monarch populations is concerning, yet this points to a much bigger and widespread situation.  Monarch butterflies are just one of the many thousands of types of pollinators.  Pollinators play a vital role in spreading the seed of fruits, vegetables, wildflowers, and trees.  To put it simply, pollinators are crucial for production of important agricultural crops, including corn, wheat, rice, apples, oranges, tomatoes, and squash.

In nature, everything is related.  In our world, everything is interconnected.

Without milkweed and other pollinating plants, butterflies, bees, moths, wasps, flies, and beetles (all pollinators!) will have no place to feed, breed, or survive.  Without these insects, the production of the food we eat will be impacted on an international level.

Survival of the Milkweed and Monarch represents survival for the rest of us.


:Enter 99 Counties:

The 99 Counties Project

We hope to plant butterfly milkweed in all 99 counties of Iowa, documenting the journey via our website blog and social media along the way.  

This provides us an opportunity to collaborate with conservation boards, non-profits, schools, or camps in each county.  During the planning and preparation stages of the project, we will reach out to contacts, referrals, and supporters of the project located in each county.  The conservation board in each county will need to be involved, so that they are aware of what we are doing and can ideally provide support.  Most of the counties have some sort of nature preserve area or park, and these will be targeted as planting locales.  

We love this project because it is accessible to everyone. All ages can participate and help plant seeds during one of our events or in their own backyards! In each county, we will do our best to arrange a planting event, inviting certain groups to join us and help plant.  To make these connections, we will ask conservation boards and non-profits for recommendations. 

What We Need & What You Get

To succeed, we need seeds!  

  1. By funding this project, you will be allowing us to purchase native Butterfly Milkweed seeds, Asclepias.  We have allotted for one ounce per county, although if our funds allow us to purchase more, we would certainly do that!  Current market price for one ounce of seed is $30.
  2. We will also be traveling across the state a handful of times to carry out the planting events.  We will be contacting county conservation boards and other entities to coordinate travel and event dates, but logistically we'd need to make a few different trips.  We'll most likely couch-surf or camp, so our travel costs will only include gas and the occasional meal.
  3. Finally, your funding will go to marketing efforts, including promotional postcards and flyers.  We will be using social media and digital means, but still see a need to reach those populations in Iowa who may not have access to internet or those who don't tweet.  

If we don't reach the entire goal, we'll do as much planting as we can with the funds we get.  Obviously, reaching the entire goal is ideal, as we don't want any counties to feel left out!

    The Impact

    By planting at least one ounce of Butterfly Milkweed seed in each of the 99 counties in Iowa, we will have made a small, yet powerful step in the right direction. Certainly, 99 ounces is a drop in the bucket compared to the total loss of 82% of milkweed in the state of Iowa.  However, our hope is that the education and advocacy that will happen along the way will make an impact in changing the ideas and misconceptions of Iowans.  By partnering with county conservation boards, schools, camps, or non-profits, we hope to spread a message of urgency about the decline of both the milkweed and monarch populations.

    We've prepared ourselves for success during our initial project, a planting and distribution campaign during RAGBRAI, the reknown bike ride across Iowa.  With funding from the Conard Environmental Research Area in Kellogg, Iowa, and 12,900 Butterfly Milkweed seeds, we began with a strong force of plantings across the state.  In just one week of social media marketing, we have 25 Facebook followers around the country, and plenty of excitement about the journey!

    Gaining momentum for this essential need is only possible with your support.

      Risks & Challenges

      We will most likely face uninformed opinions, or perspectives that may have a different priority than our own. We will face farmers whose livelihood depends on a clean, milkweed-free crop.  We will face county boards ignoring our call.  Still, we will persevere.  Don't worry: we are expecting to get our hands dirty.

      The 99 Counties Project will take many weekends to complete.  However, we are avid travelers and are a tad obsessed with exploring this state of Iowa.  Meeting interesting folks from all over the state whilst planting something that contributes to the survival of a species sounds like enough of a motivation to us.

      Perhaps the greatest risk of all is that, even when successful with the 99 Counties Project, our efforts may not make enough of a significant difference in the milkweed and Monarch populations.  Glyphosates may still prevail.  

      Please don't let glyphosates prevail.

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Maybe you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help!  The Milkweed Matters team is a firm believer in free hugs and positive energy.  Here's how you can help our spirits:

        • Write us an email with your story, opinions, or encouragement.
        • Help us get the word about our campaign by sharing this with everyone you know!
        • Do yoga poses in the shape of monarchs and milkweed!

        Milkweed Matters

        Our involvement with the conservation of milkweed began when we registered for RAGBRAI, a 10,000 person bike ride across the state of Iowa, and wanted to give back.  The RAGBRAI project involves distributing and planting 12,900 milkweed seeds along the route. It has since evolved into a larger endeavor, including this 99 Counties project. 

        We are Kelly and Carolynn, two friends transplanted to Grinnell, Iowa, both with a passion for respecting, interacting with, and contributing to the natural world around us.  Educating ourselves about the tragic loss of milkweed and, thus, a declining population of Monarch butterflies, has compelled us to act.

        In Closing

        We can't express enough how grateful we are for this opportunity to make a difference in the world around us.  We are thrilled that you are considering our project as one worthy of your support.  The milkweed and the monarchs thank you!

:Enter 99 Counties:
The 99 Counties Project We hope to plant butterfly milkweed in all 99 counties of Iowa, documenting the journey via our website blog and social media along the way.  


This provides us an opportunity to collaborate with conservation boards, non-profits, schools, or camps in each county.  During the planning and preparation stages of the project, we will reach out to contacts, referrals, and supporters of the project located in each county.  The conservation board in each county will need to be involved, so that they are aware of what we are doing and can ideally provide support.  Most of the counties have some sort of nature preserve area or park, and these will be targeted as planting locales.  
We love this project because it is accessible to everyone. All ages can participate and help plant seeds during one of our events or in their own backyards! In each county, we will do our best to arrange a planting event, inviting certain groups to join us and help plant.  To make these connections, we will ask conservation boards and non-profits for recommendations. 
What We Need & What You Get
 To succeed, we need seeds!  



By funding this project, you will be allowing us to purchase native Butterfly Milkweed seeds, Asclepias.  We have allotted for one ounce per county, although if our funds allow us to purchase more, we would certainly do that!  Current market price for one ounce of seed is $30.


We will also be traveling across the state a handful of times to carry out the planting events.  We will be contacting county conservation boards and other entities to coordinate travel and event dates, but logistically we'd need to make a few different trips.  We'll most likely couch-surf or camp, so our travel costs will only include gas and the occasional meal.


Finally, your funding will go to marketing efforts, including promotional postcards and flyers.  We will be using social media and digital means, but still see a need to reach those populations in Iowa who may not have access to internet or those who don't tweet.  


If we don't reach the entire goal, we'll do as much planting as we can with the funds we get.  Obviously, reaching the entire goal is ideal, as we don't want any counties to feel left out!

  The Impact By planting at least one ounce of Butterfly Milkweed seed in each of the 99 counties in Iowa, we will have made a small, yet powerful step in the right direction. Certainly, 99 ounces is a drop in the bucket compared to the total loss of 82% of milkweed in the state of Iowa.  However, our hope is that the education and advocacy that will happen along the way will make an impact in changing the ideas and misconceptions of Iowans.  By partnering with county conservation boards, schools, camps, or non-profits, we hope to spread a message of urgency about the decline of both the milkweed and monarch populations.
We've prepared ourselves for success during our initial project, a planting and distribution campaign during RAGBRAI, the reknown bike ride across Iowa.  With funding from the Conard Environmental Research Area in Kellogg, Iowa, and 12,900 Butterfly Milkweed seeds, we began with a strong force of plantings across the state.  In just one week of social media marketing, we have 25 Facebook followers around the country, and plenty of excitement about the journey!
Gaining momentum for this essential need is only possible with your support.

  Risks & Challenges We will most likely face uninformed opinions, or perspectives that may have a different priority than our own. We will face farmers whose livelihood depends on a clean, milkweed-free crop.  We will face county boards ignoring our call.  Still, we will persevere.  Don't worry: we are expecting to get our hands dirty.
The 99 Counties Project will take many weekends to complete.  However, we are avid travelers and are a tad obsessed with exploring this state of Iowa.  Meeting interesting folks from all over the state whilst planting something that contributes to the survival of a species sounds like enough of a motivation to us.
Perhaps the greatest risk of all is that, even when successful with the 99 Counties Project, our efforts may not make enough of a significant difference in the milkweed and Monarch populations.  Glyphosates may still prevail.  
Please don't let glyphosates prevail.

  Other Ways You Can Help Maybe you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help!  The Milkweed Matters team is a firm believer in free hugs and positive energy.  Here's how you can help our spirits: 
Write us an email with your story, opinions, or encouragement.
Help us get the word about our campaign by sharing this with everyone you know!
Do yoga poses in the shape of monarchs and milkweed!


Milkweed Matters


Our involvement with the conservation of milkweed began when we registered for RAGBRAI, a 10,000 person bike ride across the state of Iowa, and wanted to give back.  The RAGBRAI project involves distributing and planting 12,900 milkweed seeds along the route. It has since evolved into a larger endeavor, including this 99 Counties project. 
We are Kelly and Carolynn, two friends transplanted to Grinnell, Iowa, both with a passion for respecting, interacting with, and contributing to the natural world around us.  Educating ourselves about the tragic loss of milkweed and, thus, a declining population of Monarch butterflies, has compelled us to act.


In Closing

We can't express enough how grateful we are for this opportunity to make a difference in the world around us.  We are thrilled that you are considering our project as one worthy of your support.  The milkweed and the monarchs thank you!

story:
In A Nutshell

Have you ever really thought about your lunch? 

Did you know that it could be contributing to the 26 BILLION plastic sandwich bags that go into landfills each year? 

Hi! I'm Beth Race and several years ago I had one of those AHA! moments when I opened my lunch and found I was using 3 to 4 plastic sandwich bags in my lunch each day... and so were my kids. I did the research and found there were alternatives, but most of them required cleaning after using them, which means that although we are trying to do the right thing, we end up using additional energy and putting chemicals back into the environment after every use.  The other options were made of paper with some kind of unnatural coating, like petroleum-based wax and couldn't be closed tightly.  That was no good either.

I found a simple absorbent paper solution that actually works. I developed and patented Eco-Baggeez to be the best alternative to plastic sandwich bags. They are compostable and biodegrade in 2 to 5 months. They can be used very much like traditional, short term storage, sandwich bags, except that they are made of a sustainable, microwaveable paper that has been in the food industry for over 40 years.  They have a secure, resealable closure which keeps everything inside, where it's supposed to be.  Not only that, Eco-Baggeez absorb some moisture without it passing through the paper, which keeps your fruits and veggies fresh - no more mushy strawberries, bananas or sliced apples!


The Meat of the Matter

We would like to raise $50,000 through IndieGoGo to help us make a big impact on the environment. By supporting our campaign, you will help us to purchase the materials necessary to produce the initial run of our bags so that we can get them to grocery stores by the end of 2014. 

We have some pre-orders from local grocers.  They are patiently waiting for us to produce our Eco-Baggeez so we can begin supplying their retail store and their online businesses.  Some regional and national grocery store chains are very interested, but they won't commit until we prove we can make them at a certain level of production. So, we need a machine and the materials that can do that for us. Your support will make that happen.

Eco-Baggeez have not been developed overnight. In 2010 we won the Panasci Business Competition's Fetner Award for Sustainable Enterprise and were in the top ten of the Creative Core's Business Plan Competition. In the fall of 2013, I was recognized as the Entrepreneur of the Week, by Launch NY. We have been working the last four years on developing every aspect of the business from conception to prototyping, market research to producing a sample run, and we are ready to begin the production process once we receive funding. We are currently applying to the Start Up NY program which will allow us to gain access to the facilities necessary to make it all happen and help alleviate some of our expenses. And we believe in giving back. This past Spring, I mentored an Entrepreneurship Business class at our local high school, which resulted in several pretty awesome new business plans that students plan on pursuing starting this summer! 

I have been an entrepreneur for many years, and these endeavors have brought me to this point - a well rounded, experienced manager who can make this a reality. I am surrounded by experts in all areas of this business, who sit on our Advisory Board.  They are the "go to" people for consulting, issues, and resources directly related to the development of this product.  They have been invaluable throughout this entire process. David McDonough, our Financial Guru has had extensive experience working with major companies and corporations, helping to shape their financial futures. We are lucky to have him as the CFO of our company.

The Flex Plan is our funding option, as any money raised will go towards the purchase of the materials necessary for production.  We are planning to use $5,000 of the money raised for continuing pre-marketing efforts.   These will include marketing materials, as well as, expenses incurred promoting Eco-Baggeez outside of our immediate area. Our ultimate goal is to produce and sell 21,000,000 of our bags in the first year of production. 

Eco-Baggeez looks forward to thanking our supporters.  See the perks section below for details on different funding levels. 

Our Reusable grocery bags, and T-Shirt perks will be made of natural materials.  There will be two available slogans to choose from:

"Making the world greener... one lunch at a time."

and

"Green is the new black."


The Icing on the Cake

My background has been primarily technology-based, but since creating Eco-Baggeez, I have found my passion in life. I truly believe this product can make a difference. What makes it even more exciting, is that everyone who sees our sandwich bags, and tries them, is excited about them too... even people who don't consider themselves environmentally friendly.  Often times, people come up with other uses for the concept - which we plan to explore as future product lines.  The potential impact just keeps getting bigger!

Another tidbit of info: Those plastic sandwich bags I mentioned earlier take an average of 50 years to biodegrade. That means, at any given time, there are about 9 billion pounds of them in landfills in the US alone.  

I honestly think that people have been trying to do the right thing, but have limited choices in this area.  Eco-Baggeez stand out because they are made of a natural fiber, compostable material and they keep your food secure.  Our packaging is earth friendly too, using only vegetable dyes and a water-based coating. And, people can use them very much like the plastic sandwich bags they're used to.  By selling them in grocery stores, Eco-Baggeez are readily available right where you do your weekly shopping. But they will also be available online, in case a store near you is not carrying them yet.

Are you ready to help us make a difference?  Please check out the different ways you can help:

Other Ways To Help

When you think about it, putting some money, moola, green backs, lettuce, cold hard cash towards our campaign is the fastest way to help us bring this to market,  But, we could also use some help getting the word out about our product and campaign.

Please consider spreading the word through your favorite media and/or social network.  Like us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, your email trains and blogs If we all work together, we can make the world greener,,, one lunch at a time.

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Who We Are

We are Shaheen Niksefat, Michael Ginsburg, Mark Weikel, and Roby Sturgill, four undergraduate students from the University of Tennessee, Knoxville with a passion for the outdoors. We are very excited to partner with Ijams Nature Center in a campaign to raise funds to purchase a floating dock in the widely revered Mead’s Quarry. Our goal is to raise $2,600 to fund the dock, which will be an integral part for the summer programs.

Ijams is a 300-acre urban ecosystem that features 10 miles of trails that spans over a variety of terrain. Founded in 1910 by Harry Ijams, it is one of the oldest parks in Tennessee. A renowned bird-watching hotspot, Ijams offers plenty of hiking, biking, and picnic opportunities along with marble quarries to explore, river boardwalks, and beautiful wildflowers. With your help we can add this dock to the extensive list of attractions at this park.


What We Need and What You Get

Ijams Nature Center needs help purchasing the floating dock, so that Ijams can continue to provide a natural escape for the Knoxville community.  To reach our goal of helping Ijams purchase a floating dock for Mead’s Quarry, our goal is to raise a total of $2,600 for Ijams Nature Center. Your donations will help Ijams provide a safe, exciting, and well-maintained area for the Knoxville area to enjoy.

For those who join our cause, we will offer a wide range of perks. A donation of $5 will garner you a shout-out on Ijams Facebook page. If you donate $15, you can claim a vinyl Ijams car decal. A donation up to $50, can earn you a stainless steel mug along with an Ijams sticker.  For a $150 donation, you will be offered a family membership; a membership entails free and discounted family nature programs (over 200 programs), 10% discount on the gift shop, and more.

Who It Helps

Your donations will go directly toward allowing Ijams to purchase a floating dock.  This dock will provide a place for Ijams to use as a boat launch and also provide a safe area for children to play.  Water activities are an important part of what makes Ijams so unique.  By installing this dock, thousands of people can take advantage of the dock by swimming and canoeing in the quarry.

Donations will be greatly appreciated; the dock will not only sponsor the children’s summer programs, but also provide a location to launch canoes, kayaks, paddleboards, and more.


How Else Can You Help

There are many additional ways you can help the organization. You can tell friends and family members about our campaign and the importance of preserving Ijams’ natural beauty.  You can also share the link on social media pages so that the word continues to spread about our efforts to help support Ijams Nature Center.

For additional information contact Ijams at (865) 577-4717 or check out Ijams website (https://www.ijams.org).  To keep up with what Ijams is doing, follow Ijams on their Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/ijamsnaturecenter) and Twitter (https://twitter.com/ijamsnaturectr) pages.  We appreciate all donations of any size.

story:
1. A Clean Environment

A reduction in trash means a cleaner environment and improved sanitation, which will reduce occurrences of malaria, cholera, and other poor health afflictions.

2. More Cash Flow

More cash in people’s pockets means a reduction of poverty.

3. It’s Fun!

TrashCash allows for adults and youth to become more involved in their communities and enhances education on trash, recycling and sustainability.

4. A Sustainable Business

The greatest percentage of income generated will go to the users, while a portion will also go to shop owners, and the smallest percentage will be used by TrashCash to keep the business running.

5. We All Benefit

Recycling will reduce carbon emissions, mitigating climate change that impacts us all.


Thanks for reading,

Stephany



 Hello I'm Stephany - I'm the Chief Trash Officer, I love to solve challenges with a business model and as much as possible make it simple through technology. I'm software developer and a telecom engineer. Wondering what's the connection to trash?? I can't tell either. But we are set to make this happen.

Hey, I'm Chris.  With an MSc in Environment and Development from the  London  School  of  Economics  and  Political  Science (UK), the first thing I can think is let's hit the street and clear all that trash as well as empower households to sort waste. I don't want to go all about the effect of climate change but the fact this TrashCash is going to cut down a  whole lot of carbon emissions and reduce the occurrence of floods and diseases in Ghana. 


 I'm Frank, the business man, making sure we get good value for the trash we sell.
